title:
Complex symmetric, self-dual, and Ginibre random matrices: Analytical
  results for three classes of bulk and edge statistics

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Recently, a conjecture about the local bulk statistics of complex eigenvalues has been made based on numerics. It claims that there are only three universality classes, which have all been observed in open chaotic quantum systems. Motivated by these new insights, we compute and compare the expectation values of $k$ pairs of complex conjugate characteristic polynomials in three ensembles of Gaussian non-Hermitian random matrices representative for the three classes: the well-known complex Ginibre ensemble, complex symmetric and complex self-dual matrices. In the Cartan classification scheme of non-Hermitian random matrices they are labelled as class A, AI ${ }^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$, respectively. Using the technique of Grassmann variables, we derive explicit expressions for a single pair of expected characteristic polynomials for finite as well as infinite matrix dimension. For the latter we consider the global limit as well as zoom into the edge and the bulk of the spectrum, providing new analytical results for classes $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$. For general $k$, we derive the effective Lagrangians corresponding to the non-linear $\sigma$-models in the respective physical systems. Interestingly, they agree for all three ensembles, while the corresponding Goldstone manifolds, over which one has to perform the remaining integrations, are different and equal the three classical compact groups in the bulk. In particular, our analytical results show that these three ensembles have indeed different local bulk and edge spectral statistics, corroborating the conjecture further.

## 1 Introduction

It is one of the goals of statistical mechanics to derive simple, analytical models that describe universal aspects of physical systems in an approximative way. One class of such models is given by ensembles of random matrices. Their application in physics is two-fold. Firstly, they may model physical operators such as the Hamilton and the Dirac operator. Secondly, they typically belong to the wider class of static Coulomb gases with logarithmic interaction. From this point of view and at specific values of the inverse temperature $\beta$, these models can be interpreted as statistical ensembles of eigenvalues

of matrices. In the present work, we will focus on random matrices with complex eigenvalues, thus relating to a two-dimensional Coulomb gas. A prominent example is the Ginibre ensemble [1] with complex matrix elements, corresponding to $\beta=2$.

The Ginibre ensemble, non-Hermitian random matrices and Coulomb gases in general have seen a recent revival of interest in physics and mathematics, see recent reviews [2, 3, 4]. One of the reasons is that they describe open quantum mechanical systems in the regime when they become chaotic. This goes back to the work of Grobe, Haake and Sommers [5], generalising the quantum chaos conjecture for closed systems relating to Hermitian random matrices in the chaotic regime, and Poisson statistic for generic integrable quantum systems. Such and similar applications of nonHermitian random matrices include the kicked top with damping $[5,6]$, Hamiltonian systems with imaginary vector potential [7], quantum field theory with quark chemical potential $[8,9,10,11]$ as well as with lattice corrections $[12,13,14]$, quantum spin chains with dissipative disorder $[15,16,17,18]$, quantum maps $[19,20,21]$ and time-lagged correlation matrices $[22,23]$.

A crucial question to be addressed before applying random matrices is the identification of the corresponding symmetry class of the physical system under consideration. Only then the benchmarks obtained from random matrix theory can be expected to be an approximation. In the Hermitian case with real spectra, this has been facilitated through the symmetry classification by Altland and Zirnbauer [24] in the so-called ten-fold way, utilising the Cartan classification from semi-simple Lie algebras. As the authors emphasise, this is not a classification of the possible limiting eigenvalue statistics in the limit of large matrix size, but rather the classes of possible $\sigma$-models and their effective Lagrangians. For example, it turns out that for Hermitian random matrices in the bulk of the spectrum generically only three different bulk statistics result, that coincide with Dyson's earlier classification, the three-fold way [25]. In contrast, at the hard edge more limiting statistics emerge, for references and an overview over all 10 classes in the context of quantum field theory and their naive lattice discretisations see [26].

What is the situation for non-Hermitian random matrices? Based on a symmetry classification of non-Hermitian random matrices by Bernard and LeClair [27], a matrix representation was proposed by Magnea [28]. Recently, the classification [27] was revisited by Kawabata et al. [29] through the lens of topological properties, finding a total of 38 symmetry classes of non-Hermitian random matrices ${ }^{1}$. Much less is known to date about the complex eigenvalue statistics of these 38 classes. Only for 7 classes the joint probability density of the eigenvalues of the corresponding Gaussian ensembles is known for finite matrix size $N$, the three Ginibre ensembles with real, complex and quaternion matrix entries $[1,30]$, their chiral counterparts $[10,31,32]$ and the pseudo-Hermitian matrix ensemble (also known as the Wilson-Dirac random matrix in QCD) [14]. All 7 ensembles have been solved for finite- $N$ and in various large- $N$ limits, as they represent determinantal and Pfaffian point processes, see [33, 14] for a list of the corresponding kernels in these 7 classes.

It came as a surprise that only 3 different kinds of local bulk statistics have been identified in [15] amongst 9 of the 38 classes. This analysis was based on numerical computations of the nearestneighbour spacing distribution of complex eigenvalues in radial distance away from the edge and symmetry axes and points (such as the real axis and the origin) and on $N=2$ computations. The latter are actually not good approximations to the large- $N$ limit $[34]^{2}$. The authors of [15] identify a transposition symmetry to be responsible for the deformation of the bulk statistics in a subset of 9 classes. They also show numerically that these 3 bulk statistics are shared by random matrices with Gaussian and Bernoulli distributed elements and, hence, show universal characteristics. The difference between these 3 universality classes has furthermore been observed in numerical computations of their respective complex spacing ratios $[16,11]$ introduced in [16].

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ Cf. the revised version v2 of [27] that was submitted after [29] appeared.
    ${ }^{2}$ This is in stark contrast to the Wigner surmise for Hermitian ensembles, as pointed out for class A already in [5].

Due to the insights of $[15,34]$, there is a conjecture that only three universality classes of the bulk statistics for complex eigenvalues exist. Partial analytical results exist about an agreement for the limiting eigenvalue statistics within different non-Hermitian ensembles. Tao and Vu [38] have proven for a large class of complex Wigner ensembles that the local statistics in the bulk and at the edge agree with the complex Ginibre ensemble. It was also shown for the real and quaternion Ginibre ensemble that away from the real axis their limiting eigenvalue statistics agree with that of the simpler complex Ginibre ensemble in the bulk $[35,20]$ and at the edge $[36]$ of the spectrum (while they differ along the real line). Likewise, the complex Ginibre ensemble and its chiral counterpart where shown to share the same limiting statistics at the edge [37]. Hence, at least 6 of the 38 classes follow the local spectral statistics of the complex Ginibre ensemble in the bulk and at least 4 at the edge of the spectrum.

In the present work, we analytically confirm the conjecture $[15,34]$ that two symmetry classes, complex symmetric matrices (class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ ) and the $2 N$-dimensional complex self-dual random matrices (class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ ), do not follow the local statistics of the complex Ginibre ensemble (class A). These ensembles are all Gaussian to keep the analysis simple. For the complex Ginibre ensemble the nearest-neighbour spacing distribution in the bulk (as well as all other complex eigenvalue correlation functions) is well known, see [5]. However, there are no analytical results known so far for the symmetry classes $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ in the large- $N$ limit, except for the spectral density at weak non-Hermiticity for class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ in [39]. It is given in terms of a triple integral.

It is the goal of this article to start filling this gap, by providing analytical results, in particular in the global limit, local bulk and local edge scaling limit for classes $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$. We will show that in all these limits the difference amongst the 3 classes prevails. Due to the lack of an explicit expression for the joint probability density of the complex eigenvalues for the two classes $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$, we have chosen to study expectation values of products of characteristic polynomials to demonstrate their differences. For those quantities, a direct computation based on their matrix representation is feasible with the help of supersymmetric techniques, see [40] for an introduction of this method. An alternative approach uses diffusion equations [41], which has been applied to the 9 classes considered in [15], including classes $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$. In [41], a duality was derived expressing the average over $k$ pairs of characteristic polynomials with matrix size $N$ by matrix averages of dimension $k$, without taking the large- $N$ limit though. We will recover these expressions using supersymmetry.

Characteristic polynomials are useful quantities in mathematics and physics, and we refer to [42] for a review when studying Hermitian and unitary ensembles. In non-Hermitian ensembles characteristic polynomials have been employed in the replica method [43, 44, 45], offering access to the effective Lagrangian. For finite matrix size, general expressions exist for products [46] and ratios [47, 48, 49] of characteristic polynomials in general determinantal ensembles, which have been generalised to Pfaffian ensembles for products in $[50,51,52,32,13,53]$. Such relations are important for algebraic aspects of the corresponding determinantal and Pfaffian point processes, providing representations for the respective (skew-)orthogonal polynomials and their kernels, see [57, 58]. However, such direct relations do not (yet) exist for products of characteristic polynomials in classes $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$. At large- $N$ and away from the real line it was shown for products that the real and symplectic Ginibre ensemble agree [53] with the much simpler complex Ginibre ensemble [54]. The universality of products of characteristic polynomials has been explored for independent matrix entries using supersymmetric [55] and probabilistic methods [56].

Our findings presented in the ensuing sections are as follows. In Section 2, we introduce the ensembles and our notation. The main result in this section is Proposition 2.1 about the analytical expressions for a single pair of characteristic polynomials for finite matrix size $N$ which are proven in Subsection 2.3. They are given most explicitly in terms of sums of truncated exponentials in all three ensembles. Section 3 is devoted to several large- $N$ limits, also for $k=1$. We begin with the global limit, which is compared to the rescaled quantities from Subsection 2.3, plotted at various values of

$N$. To set the stage for the local scaling limits, we briefly recall the limiting results for the complex Ginibre ensemble class A in the bulk and at the edge of the spectrum. Our intention is to highlight the intimate relation between the expected pair of characteristic polynomials and the kernel as well as the spectral density, which allows to make such an identification. In Subsection 3.3, we derive new analytical expressions in class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ for the edge of the spectrum which are summarised in Theorem 3.2. The local bulk limit is covered in Proposition 3.3 in Subsection 3.4. While both results follow easily from finite matrix dimension $N$ in class A and $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$, class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ is more involved, requiring a detailed analysis. A differential equation for its integral representation is presented in Appendix A.

In Section 4, we consider expectation values of products of $k>1$ pairs of characteristic polynomials. Both limiting expressions when zooming into in the bulk (Theorem 4.1) and at the edge (Theorem 4.2) are new and can be found in Subsections 4.1 and 4.2, respectively. The former is given in terms of Itzykson-Zuber integrals [59], which are compact group integrals over the unitary, unitary-symplectic, and orthogonal group of dimensions $k$, respectively $2 k$. At the edge, the resulting group integrals of the same dimensions become non-compact, over complex, quaternion and real valued matrices. In class A these group integrals can be performed and a comparison based on previous results on orthogonal polynomials is made in Appendix B. Our conclusions and open questions are presented in Section 5.

# 2 Finite- $N$ results for a single pair of characteristic polynomials
### 2.1 Definition of the ensembles of random matrices of class $\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$

To get an idea of our techniques and results as well as have very explicitly formulas, we consider the expectation value of a product of two characteristic polynomials. One characteristic polynomial depends on the non-Hermitian random matrix $J$ and the other one on its complex conjugate $J^{*}$, i.e., the main object will be

$$
D_{N}\left(z, w^{*}\right):=\left\langle\operatorname{det}\left[z \mathbf{1}_{d_{N}}-J\right] \operatorname{det}\left[w^{*} \mathbf{1}_{d_{N}}-J^{*}\right]\right\rangle
$$

with $z, w \in \mathbb{C}$ fixed, $\mathbf{1}_{d_{N}}$ is the identity matrix of matrix dimension $d_{N}$, and $J$ is drawn from a Gaussian probability density

$$
P(J)=\frac{1}{Z_{N}} \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(J J^{\dagger}\right)\right]
$$

where the partition function $Z_{N}$ (normalisation constant) is specified below. The latter certainly strongly depends on from which non-Hermitian matrix space $J$ is taken. The average over an observable $\mathcal{O}(J)$ is denoted for all ensembles by

$$
\langle\mathcal{O}(J)\rangle:=\frac{1}{Z_{N}} \int[d J] \mathcal{O}(J) \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(J J^{\dagger}\right)\right]
$$

where $[d J]$ denotes the flat Lebesgue measure over all independent complex matrix elements. We underline that the measure $[d J]$ looks different for the three ensembles when writing it out explicitly, as the possible symmetries relate the matrix entries. This leads to $N^{2}$ complex independent elements for class $A, N(N+1) / 2$ for class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $2 N^{2}-N$ for class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$. The measure of a complex number $z=x+i y$ is chosen as $d^{2} z=d x d y$. The Hermitian conjugate of $J$ is denoted by $J^{\dagger}$.

The first and simplest ensemble, we study, has been introduced by Ginibre [1]. It is given by $N \times N$ random matrices with independent identically normal distributed complex matrix elements, $J_{i j} \in \mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{C}}(0,1)$ for $i, j=1, \ldots, N$. We adapt the notation of $[24,29,2]$ and label it with the Cartan class notation A. Its partition function reads

$$
Z_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}:=\int[d J] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(J J^{\dagger}\right)\right]=\prod_{i, j=1}^{N} \int d^{2} J_{i j} \exp \left[-\left|J_{i j}\right|^{2}\right]=\pi^{N^{2}}
$$

The second ensemble we consider consists of complex symmetric $N \times N$ matrices $J=J^{T}$. As in the complex Ginibre ensemble, the requirement of invariance under the group action $J \rightarrow U J U^{T}$ for any unitary matrix $U \in \mathrm{U}(N)$ fixes the weight up to a scaling, when assuming that all independent matrix elements are Gaussian. This however also implies that the diagonal and off-diagonal matrix elements have a different variance. We label this ensemble with $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$, see [24, 29, 2], and its partition function is
$Z_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}:=\int[d J] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(J J^{\dagger}\right)\right]=\prod_{l=1}^{N} \int d^{2} J_{l l} \exp \left[-\left|J_{l l}\right|^{2}\right] \prod_{1 \leq i<j \leq N} \int d^{2} J_{i j} \exp \left[-2\left|J_{i j}\right|^{2}\right]=\pi^{N}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)^{\frac{N(N-1)}{2}}$.
The third ensemble we consider is that of a complex self-dual $2 N \times 2 N$ random matrix $J$. In a $2 N$-dimensional complex representation it consists of 3 complex non-Hermitian matrices $A, B, C$ of size $N \times N$, where the latter two are anti-symmetric, $B^{T}=-B, C^{T}=-C$ :

$$
J=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
A & B \\
C & A^{T}
\end{array}\right), \quad \text { with } J^{\dagger}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
A^{\dagger} & -C^{*} \\
-B^{*} & A^{*}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Choosing the following embedding of the second Pauli matrix

$$
\Sigma_{y}:=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & -i \mathbf{1}_{N} \\
i \mathbf{1}_{N} & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad \Sigma_{y}^{-1}=\Sigma_{y}
$$

we have the following symmetry on $J$

$$
\Sigma_{y} J^{T} \Sigma_{y}=J
$$

This symmetry is called self-duality, and we follow [24, 29, 2] by labelling the ensemble with $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$. The corresponding partition function, thus, reads

$$
\begin{aligned}
Z_{N}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}} & :=\int[d J] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(J J^{\dagger}\right)\right] \\
& =\prod_{i, j=1}^{N} \int d^{2} A_{i j} \exp \left[-2\left|A_{i j}\right|^{2}\right] \prod_{1 \leq n<l \leq N} \int d^{2} B_{n l} d^{2} C_{n l} \exp \left[-2\left|B_{n l}\right|^{2}-2\left|C_{n l}\right|^{2}\right]=\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)^{2 N^{2}-N}
\end{aligned}
$$

It is not difficult to see from the definition of the expectation value (2.3), that for $z w^{*} \rightarrow \infty$ the right hand side of (2.1) asymptotically becomes $\sim\left(z w^{*}\right)^{N}$ for the Ginibre and $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ ensembles (matrix dimension is $d_{N}=N$ ) while it will be $\sim\left(z w^{*}\right)^{2 N}$ for the $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ ensemble because the matrices have dimension $d_{N}=2 N$.

In order to take the large- $N$ limit later, we will adjust the normalisation, where we divide (2.1) by its value at vanishing arguments,

$$
D_{N}(0,0)=\left\langle\operatorname{det}[J] \operatorname{det}\left[J^{*}\right]\right\rangle
$$

It is some natural choice of a reference point, despite that it will not cancel all $N$-dependent terms.

# 2.2 Grassmann variables and special functions 

Below we will employ anticommuting complex Grassmann variables $\xi, \psi$, i.e., $\{\xi, \psi\}=\xi \psi+\psi \xi=0$, in order to write determinants as integrals. We follow the conventions of Haake [60], and we refer to [40] for an introduction into superalgebra and superanalysis. Complex conjugation is chosen to satisfy the following relations $\left(\xi^{*}\right)^{*}=-\xi$ for single and $(\xi \psi)^{*}=\xi^{*} \psi^{*}$ for a product of Grassmann

variables. Complex conjugated variables anticommute equally, $\left\{\xi, \xi^{*}\right\}=\left\{\xi,{ }^{*} \psi\right\}=0$. The integration convention of each Grassmann variable is chosen to be

$$
\int d \xi=0, \quad \int d \xi \xi=1
$$

For a complex Grassmann vector of size $N, \xi^{T}=\left(\xi_{1}, \ldots, \xi_{N}\right)$ we, then, obtain for the determinant of an arbitrary $N \times N$ matrix $C$

$$
\operatorname{det}[C]=\int[d \xi] \exp \left[\xi^{\dagger} C \xi\right]
$$

The integration measure is defined as $[d \xi]=\prod_{i=1}^{N} d \xi_{i} d \xi_{i}^{*}$. A second identity is needed for the Pfaffian determinant of an arbitrary even dimensional antisymmetric matrix $D$ of size $2 N \times 2 N$,

$$
\operatorname{Pf}[D]=(-1)^{N(N+1) / 2} \int[d \xi] \exp \left[\frac{1}{2}\left(\xi^{T}, \xi^{* T}\right) D\binom{\xi}{\xi^{*}}\right]
$$

Finally, we would like to introduce some special functions that we will encounter repeatedly. It is well-known [1] that the truncated exponential

$$
E_{N}(x):=\sum_{j=0}^{N} \frac{x^{j}}{j!}=e^{x} \frac{\Gamma(N+1, x)}{\Gamma(N+1)}=e^{x} Q(N+1, x)
$$

plays an important role in the complex Ginibre ensemble (class A). It actually has its appearance for the other two ensembles studied by us. The truncated exponential can be rewritten in terms of the upper incomplete Gamma-function $[61,8.4 .10]$

$$
\Gamma(a, x):=\int_{x}^{\infty} d t t^{a-1} e^{-t}
$$

as well as its normalised version

$$
Q(a, x):=\frac{\Gamma(a, x)}{\Gamma(a)}
$$

At the edge of the complex Ginibre ensemble, one encounters the complementary error function

$$
\operatorname{erfc}(x)=\frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}} \int_{x}^{\infty} d t e^{-t^{2}}
$$

whose relation to the error function erf is

$$
\operatorname{erfc}(y)=1-\operatorname{erf}(y)=1+\operatorname{erf}(-y)=2-\operatorname{erfc}(-y)
$$

and to the imaginary error function

$$
\operatorname{erfi}(z)=-i \operatorname{erf}(i z)=\frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}} \int_{0}^{z} d s e^{s^{2}}
$$

Those functions can be also found in the case of complex symmetric matrices $\left(\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}\right)$ while for the case of complex self-dual matrices $\left(\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}\right)$ we encounter Owen's $T$-function [62] defined as follows,

$$
T(x, a):=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{a} d t \frac{e^{-\frac{1}{2} x^{2}\left(1+t^{2}\right)}}{1+t^{2}}, \quad x, a \in \mathbb{R}
$$

We actually need the function analytically continued to the imaginary axis in its second argument,

$$
T(x, i b)=\frac{i}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{b} d u \frac{e^{-\frac{1}{2} x^{2}\left(1-u^{2}\right)}}{1-u^{2}}, \quad x \in \mathbb{R} \quad \text { and } \quad b \in(-1,1)
$$

When going beyond the specified integral one needs to be aware of the emerging branch cuts on $b \in \mathbb{R} \backslash(-1,1)$. We will not run into this problem, though, as we avoid those cuts.

We will mention some properties of all these special functions where necessary in the computations.

# 2.3 Statement and derivation for a pair of characteristic polynomials 

We are now ready to state our first results for the expectation value of one pair of characteristic polynomials at finite matrix dimension $N$ for all three ensembles.

Proposition 2.1 (One pair of expected characteristic polynomials for finite- $N$ ).
Employing definitions (2.1) and (2.10) as well as (2.14) and (2.16), it holds for any finite $N \geq 1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}(0,0)} & =E_{N}\left(z w^{*}\right)=e^{z w^{*}} Q\left(N+1, z w^{*}\right) \\
\frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}(0,0)} & =E_{N}\left(2 z w^{*}\right)-\frac{2 z w^{*}}{N+1} E_{N-1}\left(2 z w^{*}\right) \\
& =e^{2 z w^{*}}\left(Q\left(N+1,2 z w^{*}\right)-\frac{2 z w^{*}}{N+1} Q\left(N, 2 z w^{*}\right)\right) \\
\frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}(0,0)} & =\frac{N!}{(2 N)!} \sum_{j=0}^{N} \frac{(2 j)!}{j!}\left(4 z w^{*}\right)^{N-j} E_{2 j}\left(2 z w^{*}\right) \\
& =e^{2 z w^{*}} \frac{N!}{(2 N)!} \sum_{j=0}^{N} \frac{(2 j)!}{j!}\left(4 z w^{*}\right)^{N-j} Q\left(2 j+1,2 z w^{*}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The combination of truncated exponentials in (2.23) for $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ is precisely the one appearing in the computation of the eigenvector statistics for class A, see [63, Eq. (2.16)]. This may be a total coincidence, but it is worth mentioning.

The expectation (2.22) is well-known and only a special case of a more general theorem in [46]. It was derived using the fact that the complex Ginibre ensemble (class A) is a determinantal point process, and planar orthogonal polynomials can be utilised, cf., eq. (3.12) on the relation to the kernel. For pedagogical reasons we will also derive (2.22) in class A using the supersymmetry method that generalises to the two other ensembles naturally.

We also mention in eqs. (2.22) and (2.23) the expression in terms of truncated exponentials (2.14) which become useful when taking the large- $N$ limit in the bulk of the spectrum, see Subsection 3.4. The second form of these expectation values in terms of the normalised incomplete Gamma-function (2.16) will prove useful in the edge scaling limit, shown in Subsection 3.3. Last but not least there exists a double integral representation (2.63) together with (2.59) for the result (2.24) of class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$, which is needed to derive the corresponding large- $N$ limits at the edge and in the bulk.

Class A: We begin with deriving (2.22) for the complex Ginibre ensemble. Using (2.12), the expectation value (2.1) can be written as

$$
D_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)=\int \frac{[d J]}{\pi^{N^{2}}} \int[d \xi][d \psi] \exp \left[\sum_{j, l=1}^{N}\left(-\left|J_{j l}\right|^{2}+\xi_{j}^{*}\left(z \delta_{j l}-J_{j l}\right) \xi_{l}+\psi_{j}^{*}\left(w^{*} \delta_{j l}-J_{j l}^{*}\right) \psi_{l}\right)\right]
$$

Splitting up $J_{j l}=J_{j l}^{1}+i J_{j l}^{2}$ into its real and imaginary part, the $J$-dependent part of the exponent

can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\sum_{j, l=1}^{N}\left(\left(J_{j l}^{1}\right)^{2}+J_{j l}^{1}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} \xi_{l}+\psi_{j}^{*} \psi_{l}\right)+\left(J_{j l}^{2}\right)^{2}+i J_{j l}^{2}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} \xi_{l}-\psi_{j}^{*} \psi_{l}\right)\right) \\
= & -\sum_{j, l=1}^{N}\left(\left(J_{j l}^{1}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} \xi_{l}+\psi_{j}^{*} \psi_{l}\right)\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{4}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} \xi_{l}+\psi_{j}^{*} \psi_{l}\right)^{2}\right) \\
& -\sum_{j, l=1}^{N}\left(\left(J_{j l}^{2}+\frac{i}{2}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} \xi_{l}-\psi_{j}^{*} \psi_{l}\right)\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{4}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} \xi_{l}-\psi_{j}^{*} \psi_{l}\right)^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

As the product of two Grassmann variables is again a commuting but nilpotent variable, we may shift the real and imaginary parts of the matrix elements $J_{j l}$ individually and integrate them out, to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{N}^{\Lambda}\left(z, w^{*}\right) & =\int[d \xi][d \psi] \exp \left[\sum_{j, l=1}^{N}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} z \delta_{j l} \xi_{l}+\psi_{j}^{*} w^{*} \delta_{j l} \psi_{l}+\xi_{j}^{*} \xi_{l} \psi_{j}^{*} \psi_{l}\right)\right] \\
& =\int[d \xi][d \psi] \frac{1}{\pi} \int d^{2} a \exp \left[-|a|^{2}+\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} z \xi_{j}+\psi_{j}^{*} w^{*} \psi_{j}+i a \xi_{j}^{*} \psi_{j}^{*}+i a^{*} \xi_{j} \psi_{j}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

In the first step, we multiplied out the squares of Grassmann variables. In order to do the integrals, we linearised the quartic term in the Grassmann variables with an auxiliary variable $a \in \mathbb{C}$ integrated over the complex plane, i.e.,

$$
1=\frac{1}{\pi} \int d^{2} a \exp \left[-\left(a-i \sum_{l=1}^{N} \xi_{l} \psi_{l}\right)\left(a^{*}-i \sum_{j=1}^{N} \xi_{j}^{*} \psi_{j}^{*}\right)\right]
$$

The single sum in the exponent in (2.27) is the scalar product

$$
\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} z \xi_{j}+\psi_{j}^{*} w^{*} \psi_{j}+i a \xi_{j}^{*} \psi_{j}^{*}+i a^{*} \xi_{j} \psi_{j}\right)=\left(\xi^{\dagger}, \psi^{T}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}
z \mathbf{1}_{N} & i a \mathbf{1}_{N} \\
-i a^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} & -w^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N}
\end{array}\right)\binom{\xi}{\psi^{*}}
$$

It is not difficult to see that in the integral (2.12) an exchange of variables $\xi \leftrightarrow \xi^{*}$ leads to a Jacobian of $(-1)^{N}$. This change of variables will put the scalar product in (2.29) into the form that (2.12) can be applied, in this case for a $2 N \times 2 N$ matrix. This leads to the result ${ }^{3}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{N}^{\Lambda}\left(z, w^{*}\right) & =\frac{(-1)^{N}}{\pi} \int d^{2} a e^{-|a|^{2}} \operatorname{det}\left[\begin{array}{cc}
z \mathbf{1}_{N} & i a \mathbf{1}_{N} \\
-i a^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} & -w^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N}
\end{array}\right]=\frac{1}{\pi} \int d^{2} a \exp \left[-|a|^{2}\right]\left[z w^{*}+|a|^{2}\right]^{N} \\
& =\exp \left[z w^{*}\right] \int_{z w^{*}}^{\infty} d t \exp [-t] t^{N}=e^{z w^{*}} \Gamma\left(N+1, z w^{*}\right)=N!E_{N}\left(z w^{*}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, we changed to polar coordinates $a=\sqrt{t} e^{i \phi}$ with $t$ the squared radius of $a$ and exploited (2.14) and (2.15). Because the upper incomplete Gamma-function (2.15) is analytic in its second argument we are allowed to employ it for complex $z w^{*}$, as well.

The normalisation can be readily obtained from this result,

$$
D_{N}^{\Lambda}(0,0)=N!
$$

Class $\mathbf{A I}^{\dagger}$ : Next, we show (2.23) for the ensemble of complex symmetric matrices. The average of the determinants can be expressed as in (2.25), however, we now have to take into account the symmetry $J_{j l}=J_{l j}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)=\int \frac{[d J]}{Z_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}} & \int[d \xi][d \psi] \exp \left[\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(-\left|J_{j j}\right|^{2}+\xi_{j}^{*}\left(z-J_{j j}\right) \xi_{j}+\psi_{j}^{*}\left(w^{*}-J_{j j}^{*}\right) \psi_{j}\right)\right] \\
& \times \exp \left[-\sum_{1 \leq j<l \leq N} 2\left(\left|J_{j l}\right|^{2}+J_{j l}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} \xi_{l}+\xi_{l}^{*} \xi_{j}\right)+J_{j l}^{*}\left(\psi_{j}^{*} \psi_{l}+\psi_{l}^{*} \psi_{j}\right)\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Splitting again the matrix entries into real and imaginary part, $J_{j l}=J_{j l}^{\dagger}+i J_{j l}^{2}$, the diagonal matrix elements in the exponent become,

$$
\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(-\left(J_{j j}^{\dagger}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} \xi_{j}+\psi_{j}^{*} \psi_{j}\right)\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{4}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} \xi_{j}+\psi_{j}^{*} \psi_{j}\right)^{2}-\left(J_{j j}^{2}+\frac{i}{2}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} \xi_{j}-\psi_{j}^{*} \psi_{j}\right)\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{4}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} \xi_{j}-\psi_{j}^{*} \psi_{j}\right)^{2}\right)
$$

while the upper triangular matrix elements take the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{1 \leq n<l \leq N} & \left(-2\left(J_{n l}^{\dagger}+\frac{1}{4}\left(\xi_{n}^{*} \xi_{l}+\xi_{l}^{*} \xi_{n}+\psi_{n}^{*} \psi_{l}+\psi_{l}^{*} \psi_{n}\right)\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{8}\left(\xi_{n}^{*} \xi_{l}+\xi_{l}^{*} \xi_{n}+\psi_{n}^{*} \psi_{l}+\psi_{l}^{*} \psi_{n}\right)^{2}\right. \\
& \left.-2\left(J_{n l}^{2}+\frac{i}{4}\left(\xi_{n}^{*} \xi_{l}+\xi_{l}^{*} \xi_{n}-\psi_{n}^{*} \psi_{l}-\psi_{l}^{*} \psi_{n}\right)\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{8}\left(\xi_{n}^{*} \xi_{l}+\xi_{l}^{*} \xi_{n}-\psi_{n}^{*} \psi_{l}-\psi_{l}^{*} \psi_{n}\right)^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Integrating out the shifted Gaussian matrix elements and multiplying out the quartic Grassmann terms, we obtain for (2.32) after some simplifications

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right) & =\int[d \xi][d \psi] e^{\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} z \xi_{j}+\psi_{j}^{*} w^{*} \psi_{j}+\xi_{j}^{*} \xi_{j} \psi_{j}^{*} \psi_{j}\right)+\sum_{1 \leq n<l \leq N} \frac{1}{2}\left(\xi_{n}^{*} \xi_{l}+\xi_{l}^{*} \xi_{n}\right)\left(\psi_{n}^{*} \psi_{l}+\psi_{l}^{*} \psi_{n}\right)} \\
& =\int[d \xi][d \psi] \exp \left[\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} z \xi_{j}+\psi_{j}^{*} w^{*} \psi_{j}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{n, l=1}^{N}\left(\xi_{n}^{*} \psi_{n} \xi_{l} \psi_{l}^{*}-\xi_{n}^{*} \psi_{n}^{*} \xi_{l} \psi_{l}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

In the second step, we have combined diagonal and upper triangular sums to obtain two fully factorised sums over all Grasmann variables, using their antisymmetry.

In the next step, we apply (2.28) twice, though with different choices of factors, and obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)=\int[d \xi][d \psi] & \int \frac{d^{2} a d^{2} b}{\pi^{2}} \exp \left[-|a|^{2}-|b|^{2}+\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} z \xi_{j}+\psi_{j}^{*} w^{*} \psi_{j}\right)\right] \\
& \times \exp \left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(i\left(a \xi_{j} \psi_{j}+a^{*} \xi_{j}^{*} \psi_{j}^{*}\right)+b \xi_{j} \psi_{j}^{*}+b^{*} \xi_{j}^{*} \psi_{j}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

In this form we can identify the scalar product

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(\xi_{j}^{*} z \xi_{j}+\psi_{j}^{*} w^{*} \psi_{j}\right)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(i\left(a \xi_{j} \psi_{j}+a^{*} \xi_{j}^{*} \psi_{j}^{*}\right)+b \xi_{j} \psi_{j}^{*}+b^{*} \xi_{j}^{*} \psi_{j}\right) \\
= & \left(\xi^{\dagger}, \xi^{T}, \psi^{\dagger}, \psi^{T}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
0 & \frac{1}{2} z \mathbf{1}_{N} & \frac{i}{2 \sqrt{2}} a^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} & \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}} b^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} \\
-\frac{1}{2} z \mathbf{1}_{N} & 0 & \frac{i}{2 \sqrt{2}} b \mathbf{1}_{N} & \frac{i}{2 \sqrt{2}} a \mathbf{1}_{N} \\
\frac{-i}{2 \sqrt{2}} a^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} & \frac{-1}{2 \sqrt{2}} b \mathbf{1}_{N} & 0 & \frac{1}{2} w^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} \\
\frac{-1}{2 \sqrt{2}} b^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} & \frac{-1}{2 \sqrt{2}} a \mathbf{1}_{N} & -\frac{1}{2} w^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\xi^{*} \\
\xi \\
\psi^{*} \\
\psi
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This allows us to recognise and exploit the identity (2.13) once we have changed $\xi \leftrightarrow \xi^{*}$ and $\psi \leftrightarrow \psi^{*}$ so that we arrive at

$$
D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI} \dagger}\left(z, w^{*}\right)=\int \frac{d^{2} a d^{2} b}{\pi^{2}} \exp \left[-|a|^{2}-|b|^{2}\right] \operatorname{Pf}\left[\begin{array}{cccc}
0 & z \mathbf{1}_{N} & \frac{i}{\sqrt{2}} a^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} b^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} \\
-z \mathbf{1}_{N} & 0 & \frac{i}{\sqrt{2}} b \mathbf{1}_{N} & \frac{i}{\sqrt{2}} a \mathbf{1}_{N} \\
\frac{-i}{\sqrt{2}} a^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} & \frac{-1}{\sqrt{2}} b \mathbf{1}_{N} & 0 & w^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} \\
\frac{-1}{\sqrt{2}} b^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} & \frac{-i}{\sqrt{2}} a \mathbf{1}_{N} & -w^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N} & 0
\end{array}\right]
$$

This duality formula with $k=1$ pair of integration variables over a Pfaffian determinant of size $4 N$ was independently derived in [41] using a diffusion equation rather than supersymmetry. Here, we further simplify the duality formula (2.38). Using the fact that the Pfaffian determinant of an antisymmetric matrix $G$ relates to the determinant as $\operatorname{Pf}[G]=\sqrt{\operatorname{det}[G]}$, as well as the evaluation of determinants with block matrices $A, B, C, D$ ( $A$ must be invertible) via Schur complement,

$$
\operatorname{det}\left[\begin{array}{ll}
A & B \\
C & D
\end{array}\right]=\operatorname{det}\left[A D-A C A^{-1} B\right]
$$

we can compute the Pfaffian in (2.38) which is

$$
\operatorname{det}\left[\begin{array}{cc}
-\frac{1}{2}\left(2 z w^{*}+|a|^{2}+|b|^{2}\right) \mathbf{1}_{N} & 0 \\
0 & -\frac{1}{2}\left(2 z w^{*}+|a|^{2}+|b|^{2}\right) \mathbf{1}_{N}
\end{array}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{1}{2^{N}}\left(2 z w^{*}+|a|^{2}+|b|^{2}\right)^{N}
$$

This leads to the following double integral expression for the expected characteristic polynomials

$$
D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI} \dagger}\left(z, w^{*}\right)=\int \frac{d^{2} a d^{2} b}{\pi^{2}} \exp \left[-|a|^{2}-|b|^{2}\right] \frac{1}{2^{N}}\left(2 z w^{*}+|a|^{2}+|b|^{2}\right)^{N}=\frac{1}{2^{N}} \int_{0}^{\infty} d t e^{-t} t\left(2 z w^{*}+t\right)^{N}
$$

In the second equality we have employed spherical coordinates with $t=|a|^{2}+|b|^{2}$ the squared radius. Once we shift $t \rightarrow t-2 z w^{*}$ we can anew identify the truncated exponential (2.14) and (2.15) so that

$$
D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI} \dagger}\left(z, w^{*}\right)=\frac{N!}{2^{N}}\left((N+1) E_{N}\left(2 z w^{*}\right)-2 z w^{*} E_{N-1}\left(2 z w^{*}\right)\right)
$$

This result also implies the normalisation

$$
D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI} \dagger}(0,0)=\frac{N!}{2^{N}}(N+1)
$$

Class AII ${ }^{\dagger}$ : Finally, we show (2.24) for complex self-dual matrices. Because of the doubling of the dimension, we introduce two sets of $N$-dimensional Grassmann vectors $\xi_{1}^{T}=\left(\xi_{11}, \ldots, \xi_{1 N}\right)$ and $\xi_{2}^{T}=\left(\xi_{21}, \ldots, \xi_{2 N}\right)$ and likewise the vectors $\psi_{1}^{T}$ and $\psi_{2}^{T}$. Applying the relation (2.12) and observing the block-structure of the complex self-dual matrix $J$ in (2.6) we thus obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{N}^{\mathrm{AII} \dagger}\left(z, w^{*}\right)= & \int \frac{|d A][d B][d C]}{Z_{N}^{\mathrm{AII} \dagger}} \int\left[d \xi_{1}\right]\left[d \xi_{2}\right]\left[d \psi_{1}\right]\left[d \psi_{2}\right] \\
& \times e^{\sum_{i, j=1}^{N}\left[-2\left|A_{i j}\right|^{2}+\xi_{1 i}^{*}\left(z \delta_{i j}-A_{i j}\right) \xi_{1 j}+\xi_{2 i}^{*}\left(z \delta_{i j}-A_{j i}\right) \xi_{2 j}+\psi_{1 i}^{*}\left(w^{*} \delta_{i j}-A_{i j}^{*}\right) \psi_{1 j}+\psi_{2 i}^{*}\left(w^{*} \delta_{i j}-A_{j i}^{*}\right) \psi_{2 j}\right]} \\
& \times e^{-\sum_{1 \leq l<n \leq N}\left[2\left|B_{n l}\right|^{2}+\left(\xi_{1 n}^{*} \xi_{2 l}-\xi_{1 l}^{*} \xi_{2 n}\right) B_{n l}+\left(\psi_{1 n}^{*} \psi_{2 l}-\psi_{1 l}^{*} \psi_{2 n}\right) B_{n l}^{*}\right]} \\
& \times e^{-\sum_{1 \leq l<n \leq N}\left[2\left|C_{n l}\right|^{2}+\left(\xi_{2 n}^{*} \xi_{1 l}-\xi_{2 l}^{*} \xi_{1 n}\right) C_{n l}+\left(\psi_{2 n}^{*} \psi_{1 l}-\psi_{2 l}^{*} \psi_{1 n}\right) C_{n l}^{*}\right]}
\end{aligned}
$$

Splitting again the matrix elements $A_{n l}=A_{n l}^{1}+i A_{n l}^{2}$ into real and imaginary part, we can write the exponent of all $A$-dependent parts as follows,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -2 \sum_{n, l=1}^{N}\left(\left(A_{n l}^{1}\right)^{2}+\left(A_{n l}^{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \Xi_{n l}^{+} A_{n l}^{1}+i \frac{1}{2} \Xi_{n l}^{-} A_{n l}^{2}\right) \\

\end{aligned}

where we have defined two bilinears of Grassmann variables

$$
\Xi_{n l}^{+}:=\xi_{1 n}^{*} \xi_{1 l}+\xi_{2 l}^{*} \xi_{2 n}+\psi_{1 n}^{*} \psi_{1 l}+\psi_{2 l}^{*} \psi_{2 n}, \quad \Xi_{n l}^{-}:=\xi_{1 n}^{*} \xi_{1 l}+\xi_{2 l}^{*} \xi_{2 n}-\left(\psi_{1 n}^{*} \psi_{1 l}+\psi_{2 l}^{*} \psi_{2 n}\right)

After integrating out all matrix elements of $A$, we find anew quartic terms in the Grassmann variables which are

Likewise, all terms depending on the matrix elements of $B_{n l}=B_{n l}^{1}+i B_{n l}^{2}$ in (2.44) read

Similarly, the terms depending on the matrix elements of $C_{n l}=C_{n l}^{1}+i C_{n l}^{2}$ in (2.44) give

after the integration over all matrix elements of $C$.

The sum of eqs. (2.50) and (2.53) can be combined into

$$
\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\substack{1 \leq n, l \leq N \\ n \neq l}}\left(-\xi_{1 n}^{*} \psi_{1 n}^{*} \xi_{2 l} \psi_{2 l}-\xi_{1 n}^{*} \psi_{2 n} \xi_{2 l} \psi_{1 l}^{*}-\xi_{2 n}^{*} \psi_{2 n}^{*} \xi_{1 l} \psi_{1 l}-\xi_{2 n}^{*} \psi_{1 n} \xi_{1 l} \psi_{2 l}^{*}\right)

$$
\begin{aligned}

\xi_{2}^{*} \\
\xi_{2} \\

\psi_{1} \\
\psi_{2}^{*} \\
\psi_{2}

D_{N}^{\mathrm{AII}^{1}}\left(z, w^{*}\right) & =\int \frac{d^{2} p d^{2} q}{\pi^{2}} \exp \left[-|p|^{2}-|q|^{2}\right] \frac{1}{4^{N}}\left(\left(2 z w^{*}\right)^{2}+4 z w^{*}\left(|p|^{2}+|q|^{2}\right)+\left(|p|^{2}-|q|^{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{N} \\
& =\frac{1}{4^{N}} f_{N}(x), \quad \text { with } \quad x=z w^{*} \quad \text { and } \\
f_{N}(x) & :=\int_{0}^{\infty} d r \int_{0}^{\infty} d s \exp [-r-s]\left(4 x^{2}+4 x(r+s)+(r-s)^{2}\right)^{N}
\end{aligned}
$$

after changing to polar coordinates for $q$ and $p$.
It is useful to introduce so-called light cone variables at this stage, the sum and difference of the integration variables,

$$
v:=r+s, \quad u:=r-s, \quad \text { with } v \geq 0, u \in[-v, v]
$$

The Jacobian is $d r d s=\frac{1}{2} d v d u$ so that we get, due to Fubini's theorem,

$$
f_{N}(x)=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v e^{-v} \int_{-v}^{v} d u\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N}
$$

We note in passing that this integral satisfies an inhomogenous first order differential equation as is explained in Appendix A.

The integral can be further simplified as follows. Using the evenness of the integrand with respect to variable $u \rightarrow-u$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{N}(x) & =\int_{0}^{\infty} d v \int_{0}^{v} d u e^{-v}\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N} \\
& =\int_{0}^{\infty} d u \int_{u}^{\infty} d v e^{-v}\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N} \\
& =\int_{0}^{\infty} d u \int_{0}^{\infty} d v e^{-v-u}\left(4 x v+(2 x+u)^{2}\right)^{N}
\end{aligned}
$$

In the second equality we reordered the integrals and in the third one we shifted $v \rightarrow v^{\prime}=v-u$.

This expression (2.63) leads to a simple summation formula at finite- $N$, as well as to the large- $N$ asymptotic limits performed in the next section. From a simple expansion of the binomial we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{N}(x) & =\int_{0}^{\infty} d u \int_{0}^{\infty} d v e^{-v-u} \sum_{j=0}^{N} \frac{N!}{j!(N-j)!}(4 x v)^{N-j}(2 x+u)^{2 j} \\
& =\int_{2 x}^{\infty} d u^{\prime} e^{-u^{\prime}+2 x} \sum_{j=0}^{N} \frac{N!}{j!}(4 x)^{N-j}\left(u^{\prime}\right)^{2 j} \\
& =e^{2 x} \sum_{j=0}^{N} \frac{N!}{j!}(4 x)^{N-j} \Gamma(2 j+1,2 x)
\end{aligned}
$$

after shifting again $u^{\prime}=2 x+u$ and using the definition of the incomplete Gamma-function (2.15).
At $x=z w^{*}=0$ we only have a contribution from $j=N$, and hence with $\Gamma(2 j+1,0)=(2 j)$ ! we obtain

$$
f_{N}(0)=(2 N)!
$$

and, thus, together with $(2.59)$

$$
D_{N}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}(0,0)=\frac{(2 N)!}{4^{N}}
$$

Inserting this into the definition on the left hand side of (2.24) together with (2.16) and (2.14), this proves both right hand sides of (2.24).

# 3 Asymptotic global and local large- $N$ limits for a single pair
### 3.1 Scaling with $N$ and global limit for a single pair

In this subsection, we start exploring the possible large- $N$ limits. First, we present plots for the rescaled characteristic polynomials at different values of $N$ over the entire range of the spectrum, helping us in identifying different scaling regimes. In particular, we present the global limit for all three classes, before zooming into the local edge and bulk regime in the subsequent subsections. To deal with those in a unifying way, it is useful to introduce the dimension

$$
d_{N}=N \quad \text { for } \quad \mathrm{A} \text { and } \mathrm{AI}^{\dagger} \quad \text { and } \quad d_{N}=2 N \quad \text { for } \quad \mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}
$$

and the scaling

$$
s=1 \quad \text { for } \quad \mathrm{A} \quad \text { and } \quad s=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \quad \text { for } \quad \mathrm{AI}^{\dagger} \text { and } \mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}
$$

The scaling $s$ properly normalises the limiting support of the expectation value (2.1) as well as the eigenvalues to the unit disc for all three ensembles. The latter we have checked numerically which also implies that the local mean level spacing of the eigenvalues is normalised to the same distance so that the local statistics become comparable.

Our results for the global limit can be summarised as follows.
Proposition 3.1 (Global limit for a pair of characteristic polynomials).
Let $r \geq 0$. For the rescaled characteristic polynomials

$$
F_{N}(r):=\left.\exp \left[-d_{N} z w^{*}\right] \frac{D_{N}\left(\sqrt{d_{N}} s z, \sqrt{d_{N}} s w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}(0,0)}\right|_{z w^{*}=r^{2}}
$$

cf., Proposition 2.1, we obtain the following global limits

$$
\begin{aligned}
& D_{\text {global }}^{\mathrm{A}}(r):=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} F_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}(r)=\Theta(1-r) \\
& D_{\text {global }}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}(r):=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} F_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}(r)=\left(1-r^{2}\right) \Theta(1-r) \\
& D_{\text {global }}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}(r):=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} F_{N}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}(r)=\frac{1}{1-r^{2}} \Theta(1-r)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\Theta(1-r)$ is the Heaviside step-function restricting the support to the interval $[0,1]$.
Class A: Anew, we begin with the derivation for the complex Ginibre ensemble, where it is well known that it converges to the circular law, since $F_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}(r)$ is up to a normalisation factor the global spectral density of the eigenvalues in the complex plane when $z=w$, see [1]. The rescaled quantity (3.3) can be rewritten in terms of the ratio (2.16) due to (2.22), i.e.,

$$
F_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}(r)=Q\left(N+1, N r^{2}\right)
$$

The exponential factor in (2.22) is removed, as it is well known that the remaining normalised incomplete Gamma-function has a finite limit. The global limit of this function is obtained from the convergence of the normalised lower incomplete Gamma-function [61, 8.11.6 \& 8.11.7]

$$
D_{\text {global }}^{\mathrm{A}}(r)=\Theta(1-r)
$$

The corrections are exponentially suppressed except when $r \approx 1$ where it becomes algebraic due to [61, 8.11.12]. Later, in the local edge scaling limit the step of the function $F_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}(r)$ at $r=1$ will be studied at a finer resolution, cf., eqs. (3.17) and (3.19). The results (3.5) and (3.6) are plotted in Fig. 1 (top left plot) for $N=10,20,50$ and in the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$.

Class $\mathbf{A I}^{\dagger}$ : We turn to the derivation for complex symmetric matrices. Due to the very similar form, cf., eqs. (2.22) and (2.23), the computation goes along the same lines. We would like to emphasise that the joint probability density of the eigenvalues for this ensemble is unknown, and no relation between the expected characteristic polynomials and the eigenvalue density can be expected a priori. The global spectral density is expected to satisfy the circular law with radius $\sqrt{2}$ without introducing the scaling $s$.

To have a similar situation as in the complex Ginibre ensemble, we also remove the exponential prefactor in (2.23). Once we use the result (2.23) in (3.3), we consider

$$
F_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}(r)=Q\left(N+1, N r^{2}\right)-\frac{N r^{2}}{N+1} Q\left(N, N r^{2}\right)
$$

As for class $A$, it is clear from the asymptotic of the incomplete Gamma-function [61, 8.11.6 \& 8.11.7] that we obtain for the global limit

$$
D_{\text {global }}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}(r)=\left(1-r^{2}\right) \Theta(1-r)
$$

As in class A the correction terms are exponentially suppressed when staying away from the vicinity about $r=1$. Plots of (3.7) for $N=10,20,50$ and (3.8) for $N \rightarrow \infty$ can be found in Fig. 1 (top right plot).

Class $\mathbf{A I I}^{\dagger}$ : The case of the complex self-dual ensemble is more involved. We start like before with properly scaling the spectral variables $z$ and $w^{*}$ and then removing the exponential prefactor in (2.24),

$$
F_{N}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}(r)=\sum_{j=0}^{N} \frac{N!(2 N-2 j)!}{(2 N)!(N-j)!}\left(4 N r^{2}\right)^{j} Q\left(2 N-2 j+1,2 N r^{2}\right)
$$

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1: Plots of the rescaled characteristic polynomials for finite- $N$ as a function of $r=z w^{*} \geq 0$ for $N=10,20,50$ (dotted orange, dashed green, solid red, respectively) and the global limit $N \rightarrow \infty$ (thick blue). Top left: rescaled density of the complex Ginibre ensemble (3.5) (class A); Top right: rescaled characteristic polynomials for the complex symmetric ensemble (3.7) (class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ ); Bottom: rescaled characteristic polynomials for the complex self-dual ensemble (3.9) (class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ ). The position of the edge of the global limit is rescaled to unity.

We have renamed the summation index $j \rightarrow N-j$ as the main contribution for $N \rightarrow \infty$ comes from a neighbourhood where $j$ is of order one. The summands have indeed a point wise limit

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{N!(2 N-2 j)!}{(2 N)!(N-j)!}\left(4 N r^{2}\right)^{j} Q\left(2 N-2 j+1,2 N r^{2}\right)=r^{2 j} \Theta(1-r)
$$

for any fixed $j$, due Stirling's approximation for the factorials and the asymptotic of the incomplete Gamma-function [61, 8.11.6 \& 8.11.7]. One can even relax the fixed condition of $j$ and allow any $j=o(\sqrt{N})$ when considering the Taylor expansion of the summands. We omit here to show that there is actually a sequence of $N$-independent summands whose series converges. This would be needed to be allowed to apply Lebesgue's dominated convergence theorem.

Summarising, we obtain a geometric series

$$
D_{\text {global }}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}(r) \approx \sum_{j=0}^{\infty} r^{2 j} \Theta(1-r)=\frac{1}{1-r^{2}} \Theta(1-r)
$$

which is drawn in Fig. 1 (bottom plot) as well as for the values $N=10,20,50$ of the finite- $N$ expression (3.9).

Let us remark again that in both classes $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ the rescaled characteristic polynomials do not directly relate to the eigenvalue density as it is the case in class A, though some kind of relation will be still present. Therefore, the quantity $D_{\text {global }}(r)$ is not normalised nor it is guaranteed to be normalisable as we can see in the class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ for which (3.11) is not integrable over its support. Indeed, the integrals over their finite- $N$ expressions depend on the matrix dimension.

The question remains how we can interpret the different shapes of the curves in Fig. 1. In [34], the local nearest-neighbour spacing distribution in radial distance in the bulk of the spectrum was compared for complex symmetric and complex self-dual matrices to the one of the two-dimensional Coulomb gas as a function of inverse temperature $\beta$ (the Dyson index). Fitting the value of $\beta$ accordingly, the following values of $\beta \approx 1.4\left(\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}\right)$ and $\beta \approx 2.6\left(\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}\right)$ were found in [34]. This approximate local description by a two-dimensional Coulomb gas was further corroborated by fitting also the next-to-nearest-neighbour spacing distributions, that confirm these approximate values of $\beta$, see [18]. Furthermore, perturbation theoretic methods [64] as well as recent numerical simulations [65] show that for $\beta>2$ the spectral density of the two-dimensional Coulomb gas overshoots the $\beta=2$ result in the neighbourhood of the edge and eventually starts to oscillate when increasing $\beta$ even further, cf., [64, Figure 1] and [65, Figure 4]. The overshooting is also visible for class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ for the average of a pair of characteristic polynomials, see bottom plot of Fig. 1. In contrast, for $\beta<2$ the authors of [65] found a damping of the spectral density at the edge compared to $\beta=2$, see Figure 2 therein, which agrees with what we found for the pair of characteristic polynomials in the top right plot of Fig. 1 for class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$. Thus, our analytical findings in the present work are consistent with the (approximate) values of $\beta \approx 1.4$ and $\beta \approx 2.6$ for the ensembles $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ for their respective local bulk statistics.

We conclude that although we have to emphasise that the expectation value of two characteristic polynomials does not have any known relation to the spectral density in the $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ or $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ ensemble, the behaviour just described is consistent with the heuristically determined $\beta$-values in [34, 18], and the properties of a two-dimensional Coulomb gas in $[64,65]$. For this reason we expect that the expectation value of two characteristic polynomials contains important information about the spectrum, too, at least at the edge of the spectrum.

# 3.2 Complex Ginibre ensemble: Edge and bulk scaling of the density revisited 

In this subsection, we briefly recall the edge and bulk scaling limit of the complex Ginibre ensemble, which is a determinantal point process with kernel $K_{N}\left(z, w^{*}\right)$. We choose the convention that $K_{N}\left(z, w^{*}\right)$ denotes the polynomial part of the kernel, without the corresponding weight functions, which is also know as pre-kernel. In this form it equals the normalised expectation value of two conjugate characteristic polynomials.

The following relation is known between this kernel at finite- $N$ and the characteristic polynomials, e.g., see $[1,46]$,

$$
K_{N}(z, w)=\frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}(0,0)}=E_{N}\left(z w^{*}\right)=e^{z w^{*}} Q\left(N+1, z w^{*}\right)
$$

The eigenvalue density is given by the kernel at equal arguments, times the weight function of the Ginibre ensemble, $w(z)=\exp \left[-|z|^{2}\right]$,

$$
R_{1, N}(z)=e^{-|z|^{2}} K_{N}\left(z, z^{*}\right)=Q\left(N+1,|z|^{2}\right)
$$

We would like to point out that this density is normalised to $N$.
In the global large- $N$ limit it converges to the circular law on a disc of radius $\sqrt{N}$ in this normalisation,

$$
R_{1, N}(z) \sim \Theta(\sqrt{N}-|z|)
$$

A further rescaling $z \rightarrow \sqrt{N} z$ maps the support to the unit disc.
The local bulk scaling limit is defined as follows. We pick a point $\sqrt{N} z_{0}$ in the bulk of the spectrum, that is with $\left|z_{0}\right|<1$. The vicinity of this bulk point is then parametrised as follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
z & =\sqrt{N} z_{0}+\chi, \quad w^{*}=\sqrt{N} z_{0}^{*}+\eta^{*} \\
x & :=z w^{*}=N\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}+\sqrt{2 N} y+\chi \eta^{*}, \quad y:=\left(\chi z_{0}^{*}+\eta^{*} z_{0}\right) / \sqrt{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The limiting kernel in the bulk is, then, obtained by replacing the truncated sum $E_{N}\left(z w^{*}\right)$ in (3.12) by an exponential, leading to

$$
K_{\text {bulk }}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right)=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} K_{N}\left(\sqrt{N} z_{0}+\chi, \sqrt{N} z_{0}^{*}+\eta^{*}\right)\left|{ }_{|z_{0}|<1} \sim \exp \left[N\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}+\sqrt{2 N} y+\chi \eta^{*}\right]\right.
$$

Strictly speaking, the pre-kernel does not have a limit. Only after multiplying with the weight function, $e^{-\frac{1}{2}\left(|z|^{2}+|w|^{2}\right)} K_{N}\left(z, w^{*}\right)$ and after cancelling cocycles that drop out in the determinant of the $k$-point correlation function, it does lead to the limiting Ginibre kernel. This is why below we will remove the exponential factor in (3.12) when taking limits. Nevertheless, the bulk asymptotic (3.16) and edge asymptotic below will be very useful when comparing results for averages over more than one pair of characteristic polynomials, cf., Appendix B.

Turning to the local edge scaling limit, we will choose the same rescaling as in (3.15), but require now that the point we zoom in is located on the unit circle, that is $\left|z_{0}\right|=1$. For the edge scaling we rewrite the truncated exponential function in the following way,

$$
E_{N}(x)=e^{x} Q(N+1, x)=e^{x}(1-P(N+1, x))
$$

where

$$
P(N+1, x)=\frac{\gamma(N+1, x)}{\Gamma(N+1)}
$$

is the regularised lower incomplete Gamma-function $\gamma(a, x)=\Gamma(a)-\Gamma(a, x)$. It enjoys the following asymptotic $[61,8.11 .10]$ for large- $N$, with the edge rescaling (3.15) at $\left|z_{0}\right|=1$,

$$
P(N+1, x)=\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{erfc}(-y)+\mathcal{O}\left(N^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)
$$

with the complementary error function (2.17). Once, we employ the identity (2.18), we find

$$
Q(N+1, x)=\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{erfc}(y)+\mathcal{O}\left(N^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)
$$

and hence the edge scaling asymptotic becomes

$$
K_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right)=\left.\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} K_{N}\left(\sqrt{N} z_{0}+\chi, \sqrt{N} z_{0}^{*}+\eta^{*}\right)\right|_{\left|z_{0}\right|=1} \sim \frac{1}{2} \exp \left[N+\sqrt{2 N} y+\chi \eta^{*}\right] \operatorname{erfc}(y)
$$

After multiplying it with the weight function and removing cocycles, it leads to the universal complementary error function kernel (sometimes called Faddeyeva plasma-kernel [66]).

# 3.3 Local edge scaling limit for one pair of characteristic polynomials 

Because only one of the three ensembles we consider is a determinantal point process, the complex Ginibre ensemble, we do not have the freedom to remove $N$-dependent cocycles from the limiting characteristic polynomials which are proportional to the kernel, nor can we argue why to multiply

with a weight function as in the Ginibre class A, which removes the leading contribution $\exp \left[N\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right]$ from the expected characteristic polynomials in that case.

Therefore, we choose a different route in defining the limiting characteristic polynomials, by removing the exponential prefactor $\exp \left[z w^{*}\right]$ that appears in all three ensembles, see eqs. (2.22), (2.23) and (2.24), respectively. Furthermore, as in the expressions for finite matrix dimension $N$ given in Proposition 2.1, we divide by the value of the respective characteristic polynomials at the origin, $D_{N}(0,0)$. It turns out that for classes $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ an additional rescaling in powers of $N^{ \pm 1 / 2}$ is necessary.

Theorem 3.2 (Local limits of a pair of characteristic polynomials at the spectral edge).
We recall the definitions (3.1), (3.2) as well as Owen's T-function (2.21) and the results of Proposition 2.1. The vicinity of edge points is defined as

$$
z=\sqrt{d_{N}} s z_{0}+s \chi, \quad w^{*}=\sqrt{d_{N}} s z_{0}^{*}+s \eta^{*}, \quad z w^{*}=s^{2}\left(d_{N}+\sqrt{2 d_{N}} y+\chi \eta^{*}\right)
$$

with $\left|z_{0}\right|=1$ and $y=\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi+z_{0} \eta^{*}\right) / \sqrt{2}$. With this rescaling we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) & :=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} e^{-z w^{*}} \frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}(0,0)}=\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{erfc}(y) \\
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) & :=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \sqrt{N} e^{-2 z w^{*}} \frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}(0,0)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{-y^{2}}-\frac{y}{\sqrt{2}} \operatorname{erfc}(y) \\
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) & :=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 N}} e^{-2 z w^{*}} \frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}(0,0)} \\
& =\left(-\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{4} \operatorname{erfc}(y) \operatorname{erfi}(y / \sqrt{2})-i \sqrt{\pi} T(\sqrt{2} y, i / \sqrt{2})\right) e^{-y^{2} / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The corresponding left and right tail asymptotic read (for real $y$ )

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) & \sim\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{\pi} y} e^{-y^{2}}, & \text { for } y \rightarrow+\infty \\
1+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{\pi} y} e^{-y^{2}}, & \text { for } y \rightarrow-\infty
\end{array}\right. \\
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) & \sim\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
\frac{1}{\sqrt{8 \pi} y^{2}} e^{-y^{2}}, & \text { for } y \rightarrow+\infty \\
-\sqrt{2} y+\frac{1}{\sqrt{8 \pi} y^{2}} e^{-y^{2}}, & \text { for } y \rightarrow-\infty
\end{array}\right. \\
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) & \sim\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
\frac{1}{\sqrt{8 \pi} y^{2}} e^{-y^{2}}, & \text { for } y \rightarrow+\infty \\
-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} y}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} y^{3}}, & \text { for } y \rightarrow-\infty
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

The asymptotic (3.24) also follows from [63, Corollary 2] for the eigenvector statistics as the initial expression (2.23) has been the same.

From the results (3.23)-(3.25) we can readily read off the value of these normalised expectation values at $\chi=\eta^{*}=0$ which is

$$
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{A}}(0,0)=\frac{1}{2}, \quad D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AI}}(0,0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \quad \text { and } \quad D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AII}}(0,0)=\frac{\operatorname{arctanh}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)}{\sqrt{4 \pi}}
$$

![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Figure 2: Plots of the expectation value of a pair of characteristic polynomials in the edge scaling limit as a function of a real $y=\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi+z_{0} \eta^{*}\right) / \sqrt{2}$, which can be achieved by setting $\chi=y / \sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*}$ and $\eta^{*}=y / \sqrt{2} z_{0}$. We normalised the expectation value by its value at $\chi=\eta^{*}=0$ for comparability which is given by (3.29). The curve for class A (solid blue) with $D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right)$ from (3.23) normalised by $D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{A}}(0,0)$ saturates at 2 . Class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ (dashed orange) given by (3.24) has a clearly visible linear rise, and class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ (dotted red) following (3.25) shows the decay $\sim-1 / \sqrt{2} y$ which starts to be visible for large negative values of $y$.

For $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$, we need Owen's $T$-function at $x=0$ in its first argument, see (2.21), which is an elementary integral. We need the values (3.29) when going over to an average over $k \geq 1$ pairs of characteristic polynomials, see Theorem 4.2 .

We would like to highlight that the edge limits of all three ensembles are translation invariant along the boundary since they only depend on $y$ and not on $\chi$ and $\eta^{*}$ independently. Indeed, when shifting $\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) \rightarrow\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right)+t\left(z_{0},-z_{0}^{*}\right)$ the variable $y$ remains unchanged, see (3.15). This could be expected for a smooth boundary of the global support because in the local limit the boundary will be well-approximated by its tangent at this point so that the edge will follow this straight line.

Theorem 3.2 implies that at the edge of the spectrum we indeed found three different classes of limiting characteristic polynomials. They are conjectured to be universal based on numerics and symmetry arguments [29]. They are plotted in Fig. 2 for illustration and comparison.

The difference between the three ensembles is obvious. It is perhaps simplest to see in the left tail asymptotic, $y \rightarrow-\infty$ for which we have given not only the leading but also the next to leading order. For the complex Ginibre ensemble the limiting characteristic polynomial saturates to unity, the mean value of the spectral density, whereas for the classes $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ a linear rise and an algebraic decay dominates, respectively, cf., Fig. 1. The right tail in the complex Ginibre ensemble was noted first in [44] for the decay of the density at the edge.

We can only speculate why a different scaling is needed in all three ensembles in the edge scaling limit. For comparison, in the real and quaternion Ginibre ensembles the corresponding skew-symmetric

kernel, that relates to the spectral density, is obtained from the expectation value of two characteristic polynomials after multiplying, respectively dividing by the difference of the arguments. When rescaling them with $\sqrt{N}$ as it is done here, this will also give rise to extra powers in $\sqrt{N}$. Our choice of the numerical part of the scaling is natural as we multiply with $\sqrt{d_{N}}=\sqrt{N}$ for $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and divide by $1 / \sqrt{d_{N}}=1 / \sqrt{2 N}$

Class A: The edge limit of the complex Ginibre ensemble is well known and has been summarised in the previous subsection, especially one needs to insert the expansion (3.19) together with (3.17) into the definition (3.23) and (2.22) to arrive at the claim. The tail asymptotic (3.26) follows from the expansion of the complementary error function $[61,7.12 .1]$

$$
\operatorname{erfc}(z) \sim\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
\frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi} z} e^{-z^{2}}\left(1-\frac{1}{2 z^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(z^{-4}\right)\right), & \text { for } z \rightarrow+\infty \\
2+\frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi} z} e^{-z^{2}}\left(1-\frac{1}{2 z^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(z^{-4}\right)\right), & \text { for } z \rightarrow-\infty
\end{array}\right.
$$

where we give the next-to-leading order, as well.
Class AI ${ }^{\dagger}$ : For the complex symmetric ensemble, it is preferable to write $E_{N-1}(x)=\partial_{x} E_{N}(x)=$ $\partial_{x}\left(e^{x} Q(N+1, x)\right)$ in (2.23). Let us mention again that the scaling with $s=1 / \sqrt{2}$ guarantees the unit disc as the limiting support. Proceeding as for the Ginibre ensemble, we multiply (2.23) with $e^{-2 z w^{*}}$ to cancel the exponential and set $x=2 z w^{*}=N+\sqrt{2 N} y+\chi \eta^{*}$,

$$
e^{-2 z w^{*}} \frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}(0,0)}=Q(N+1, x)-\frac{x e^{-x}}{N+1} \partial_{x}\left(e^{x} Q(N+1, x)\right)
$$

With help of the edge rescaling (3.22) at $\left|z_{0}\right|=1$ and the asymptotic (3.20) with $y=\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi+z_{0} \eta^{*}\right) / \sqrt{2}$, we arrive at

$$
\begin{aligned}
e^{-2 z w^{*}} \frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}(0,0)}= & \frac{1}{2} \operatorname{erfc}(y)+\mathcal{O}\left(N^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right) \\
& -\frac{N+\sqrt{2 N} y+\chi \eta^{*}}{N+1}\left(1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 N}} \partial_{y}\right)\left(\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{erfc}(y)+\mathcal{O}\left(N^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)\right) \\
= & -\frac{y}{\sqrt{2 N}} \operatorname{erfc}(y)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi N}} e^{-y^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{N}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The two order one terms cancel after expanding the ratio in $1 / N$. Eventually, we multiply with $\sqrt{N}$ to find the result (3.24).

For the tail asymptotic we insert (3.30) into (3.24) and see that the leading order Gaussian decay cancels for the right tail, $y \rightarrow+\infty$

$$
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) \sim-y \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi} y} e^{-y^{2}}\left(1-\frac{1}{2 y^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(y^{-4}\right)\right)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{-y^{2}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{8 \pi} y^{2}} e^{-y^{2}}\left(1+\mathcal{O}\left(y^{-2}\right)\right)
$$

The errors are uniform for any compact set where $y$ can be drawn from so that the derivative can indeed be interchanged with the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$.

For the left tail with $y \rightarrow-\infty$, we obtain from the corresponding asymptotic (3.30) of the complementary error function,

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) & \sim \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{-y^{2}}-\frac{y}{\sqrt{2}}\left(2+\frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi} y} e^{-y^{2}}\left(1-\frac{1}{2 y^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(y^{-4}\right)\right)\right) \\
& =-\sqrt{2} y+\frac{1}{\sqrt{8 \pi} y^{2}} e^{-y^{2}}\left(1+\mathcal{O}\left(y^{-2}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

a linear rise in $y$ (as $y<0$ ) as the leading term.
Class AII ${ }^{1}$ : For the remaining ensemble of complex self-dual matrices, we cannot use standard asymptotic results. Our starting point is the integral representation (2.63) of (2.24) in the derivation for finite $N$, that we repeat for the readers' convenience:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left.\frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}(0,0)}\right|_{x=z w^{*}} & =\frac{1}{(2 N)!} f_{N}(x), \quad f_{N}(x)=\int_{0}^{\infty} d v \int_{0}^{\infty} d u e^{S(u, v)} \\
S(u, v) & :=-u-v+N \log \left(4 x v+(2 x+u)^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This calls for a Laplace approximation at large $N$. Any critical point $\left(u_{*}, v_{*}\right)$ satisfies

$$
0=\partial_{v} S\left(u_{*}, v_{*}\right)=-1+\frac{4 N x}{4 x v_{*}+\left(2 x+u_{*}\right)^{2}} \quad \text { and } \quad 0=\partial_{u} S\left(u_{*}, v_{*}\right)=-1+\frac{2 N\left(2 x+u_{*}\right)}{4 x v_{*}+\left(2 x+u_{*}\right)^{2}}
$$

Inserting the first into the second equation yields $u_{*}=0$, and reinserted into the first equation gives $v_{*}=N-x$.

To figure out whether the point $\left(u_{*}, v_{*}\right)$ is the global maximum of $S(u, v)$ we need to compare it with the extrema along the two boundaries. For the boundary $u=0$ and $v \geq 0$,

$$
0=\partial_{v} S(0, v)=-1+\frac{N}{v+x}
$$

we find the same point $\left(u_{*}, v_{*}\right)$, whereas along the boundary $u \geq 0$ and $v=0$

$$
0=\partial_{u} S\left(u_{0}, 0\right)=-1+\frac{2 N}{2 x+u_{0}}
$$

we find $\left(u_{0}, v_{0}\right)=(2(N-x), 0)$. Taking the second derivative confirms that both extrema are indeed local maxima. However, when inserting the scaling limit (3.22) with $x=N+\sqrt{N} y+\chi \eta^{*} / 2$, since $d_{N}=2 N$ and $s=1 / \sqrt{2}$, we see that both maxima $\left(v_{*}, u_{*}\right)$ and $\left(u_{0}, v_{0}\right)$ are only within the integration domain $v, u \geq 0$ for negative values $y<0$. This can be expected as this is the direction into the bulk of the spectrum which becomes immediate when setting $z=w$.

What is more important is that the leading order of both extrema is $\sqrt{N}$ which is the same scale as the standard deviations of the Gaussians once we would expand about these points. This means that even an expansion about the origin would cover all relevant contributions from this integral. To pursue this direction we rescale $v=\sqrt{N} v^{\prime}$ and $u=2 \sqrt{N} u^{\prime}$,

$$
f_{N}(x)=(2 N)^{2 N+1} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v^{\prime} \int_{0}^{\infty} d u^{\prime} \exp \left[-\sqrt{N} v^{\prime}-2 \sqrt{N} u^{\prime}+N \log \left(\frac{x v^{\prime}}{N^{3 / 2}}+\left(\frac{x}{N}+\frac{u^{\prime}}{\sqrt{N}}\right)^{2}\right)\right]
$$

The logarithm can be expanded as follows,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \log \left[\frac{x v^{\prime}}{N^{3 / 2}}+\left(\frac{x}{N}+\frac{u^{\prime}}{\sqrt{N}}\right)^{2}\right] \\
= & \log \left[1+\frac{v^{\prime}+2 u^{\prime}+2 y}{\sqrt{N}}+\frac{1}{N}\left(y v^{\prime}+\left(y+u^{\prime}\right)^{2}+\chi \eta^{*}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{v^{\prime}+u^{\prime}}{N^{3 / 2}}\right)\right] \\
= & 1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\left(v^{\prime}+2 u^{\prime}+2 y\right)-\frac{1}{N}\left(\frac{\left(v^{\prime}\right)^{2}}{2}+\left(u^{\prime}\right)^{2}+y^{2}+2 v^{\prime} u^{\prime}+v^{\prime} y+2 u^{\prime} y-\chi \eta^{*}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\left(v^{\prime}\right)^{3}+\left(u^{\prime}\right)^{3}}{N^{3 / 2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This expansion can be stopped at the second order as long as $\left(v^{\prime}\right)^{3}+\left(u^{\prime}\right)^{3} \ll \sqrt{N}$ because the logarithm is multiplied with $N$. This restriction is, nonetheless, not a problem since already for $v^{\prime}+u^{\prime} \geq N^{\varepsilon}$ for any fixed $\varepsilon>0$ the integrand in (3.39) times $e^{-2 \sqrt{N} y}$ is exponentially small which we omit to show here. It is essentially due to the fact that the maximum of the integrand in the region $v^{\prime}+u^{\prime} \geq N^{\varepsilon}$ is attained on the boundary $v^{\prime}+u^{\prime}=N^{\varepsilon}$, because the directional derivative of $S(u, v)$ is always negative when the direction vector is non-zero and has non-negative entries, cf. the partial derivatives (3.36) which are negative in this region.

Summarising, it is asymptotically

$$
f_{N}(x) \sim(2 N)^{2 N+1} e^{2 \sqrt{N} y-y^{2}+\chi \eta^{*}} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v \int_{0}^{\infty} d u e^{-u^{2}-\frac{1}{2} v^{2}-y(v+2 u)-2 v u}
$$

when $N \rightarrow \infty$. Consequently, the full expression together with the scaling (3.22) reads to leading order

$$
\frac{e^{-2 z w^{*}}}{\sqrt{2 N}} \frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AH}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AH}^{\dagger}}(0,0)} \sim \frac{(2 N)^{2 N+1}}{\sqrt{2 N}(2 N)!} e^{-2 N-y^{2}} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v \int_{0}^{\infty} d u e^{-u^{2}-\frac{1}{2} v^{2}-y(v+2 u)-2 v u}
$$

After we exploit the Stirling formula $(2 N)!\approx \sqrt{2 \pi}(2 N)^{2 N+1 / 2} e^{-2 N}$, we are allowed to take the large- $N$ limit leading to

$$
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AH}^{\dagger}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{-y^{2}} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v \int_{0}^{\infty} d u e^{-u^{2}-\frac{1}{2} v^{2}-y(v+2 u)-2 v u}
$$

We can simplify this expression further when substituting $v^{\prime}=(v+y) / \sqrt{2}$ and $u^{\prime}=u+v+y$

$$
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AH}^{\dagger}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}} e^{-y^{2} / 2} \int_{y / \sqrt{2}}^{\infty} d v^{\prime} e^{+\frac{1}{2} v^{\prime 2}} \int_{\sqrt{2} v^{\prime}}^{\infty} d u^{\prime} e^{-u^{\prime 2}}=\frac{1}{2} e^{-y^{2} / 2} \int_{y / \sqrt{2}}^{\infty} d v e^{v^{2}} \operatorname{erfc}(\sqrt{2} v)
$$

where we employed the definition (2.17) of the complementary error function. To get a closed expression as stated in (3.25), we make the ansatz

$$
g^{\prime}(v)=-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{erfc}(\sqrt{2} v) e^{v^{2}}
$$

cf., Appendix A, which would simplify the integral (3.44) as follows

$$
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AH}^{\dagger}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right)=e^{-y^{2} / 2}(g(y / \sqrt{2})-g(+\infty))
$$

This approach is motivated by the fact that the original integral (2.62) satisfies an inhomogenous first order differential equation, as derived in the Appendix A. Here, we directly solve the differential equation (3.45) for $g(v)$.

For this purpose, we make use of Owen's $T$-function with an imaginary number in its second entry (2.21). Its derivative in its first entry is explicitly given by

$$
\partial_{x} T(x, i b)=-\frac{i x}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{b} d u e^{-\frac{1}{2} x^{2}\left(1-u^{2}\right)}=-\frac{i}{\sqrt{8 \pi}} e^{-x^{2} / 2} \operatorname{erfi}\left[\frac{b x}{\sqrt{2}}\right]
$$

Thence, when choosing $x=2 v$ and $b=1 / \sqrt{2}$, the derivative of

$$
g(v)=-\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{4} \operatorname{erfc}(\sqrt{2} v) \operatorname{erfi}(v)-i \sqrt{\pi} T\left(2 v, \frac{i}{\sqrt{2}}\right)
$$

solves the differential equation (3.45).
We still have to determine $g(+\infty)$. While the asymptotic of the complementary error function is given in (3.30), for the error function at imaginary argument we have [67]

$$
\operatorname{erfi}(v)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi} v} e^{+v^{2}}\left(1+\frac{1}{2 v^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(1 / v^{4}\right)\right)
$$

which is even valid for both $y \rightarrow \pm \infty$. Therefore, for the first term in (3.48) we obtain

$$
-\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{4} \operatorname{erfc}(\sqrt{2} v) \operatorname{erfi}(v) \sim \begin{cases}-\frac{1}{4 \sqrt{2 \pi} v^{2}} e^{-v^{2}}\left(1+\frac{1}{4 v^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(v^{-4}\right)\right), & \text { for } v \rightarrow+\infty \\ -\frac{1}{2 v} e^{+v^{2}}\left(1+\frac{1}{2 v^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(v^{-4}\right)\right), & \text { for } v \rightarrow-\infty\end{cases}
$$

implying that it vanishes for $v \rightarrow+\infty$. For the tail asymptotic, we also give the expansion for $v \rightarrow-\infty$.
We did not find the asymptotic of Owen's $T$-function in the literature. Hence, we present a short derivation. Starting from (2.21), the substitution $z=\left(1-u^{2}\right) v^{2}$ leads to

$$
\begin{aligned}
-i \sqrt{\pi} T(2 v, i / \sqrt{2}) & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{8 \pi} v^{2}} e^{-v^{2}} \int_{0}^{v^{2}} d z e^{-z}\left(1+\frac{z}{v^{2}}\right)^{-1}\left(1-\frac{z}{v^{2}}\right)^{-1 / 2} \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{8 \pi} v^{2}} e^{-v^{2}} \int_{0}^{v^{2}} d z e^{-z}\left[1-\frac{1}{2} \frac{z}{v^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{z^{2}}{v^{4}}\right)\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{8 \pi} v^{2}} e^{-v^{2}}\left[1-\frac{1}{2 v^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{v^{4}}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where in the last step we used elementary integrals. The expansion of the integrand is only uniform when cutting off at $z \leq v^{\varepsilon} \ll v^{2}$ for any constant $\varepsilon \in(0,2)$. Like before this is not a problem as the integrand is uniformly bounded from above by $e^{-v^{\varepsilon}} / \sqrt{1-z / v^{2}}$ when $z \in\left(v^{\varepsilon}, v^{2}\right)$, whose integral thus vanishes exponentially for $v \rightarrow \infty$.

Let us remark that the expansion in $1 / v$ holds for both $y \rightarrow \pm \infty$; in particular, it vanishes in both limits. As a result, the asymptotic yields $g(+\infty)=0$ so that the full solution for the edge scaling limit from (3.46) is given by (3.25).

After having evaluated the asymptotic of $g(v)$ already in great detail, we can immediately give the tail estimates. For $y \rightarrow+\infty$, it is

$$
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) \sim e^{-y^{2}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{8 \pi} y^{2}}\left(1-\frac{5}{2 y^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(y^{-4}\right)\right)
$$

where both terms in (3.25) contribute to the same order. For $y \rightarrow-\infty$, the asymptotic of the complementary error function (3.30) gives the leading contribution while Owen's $T$-function can be neglected. Thence, it is

$$
D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) \sim-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} y}\left(1+\frac{1}{y^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(y^{-4}\right)\right)+e^{-y^{2}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi} y^{2}}\left(1+\mathcal{O}\left(y^{-2}\right)\right)
$$

which completes the derivation of (3.28). We note that for negative $y$ this is a positive function.
All three limiting characteristic polynomials at the edge are plotted in Fig. 2. The difference is most pronounced at large negative $y$. While class A leads to a constant (density), in class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ there is a linear rise $\sim y$ of the rescaled characteristic polynomial, whereas in class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ it decays proportional to $\sim 1 / y$. This is in line with the plots at finite matrix dimension $N$ in Fig. 1, where here we zoom into the edge behaviour.

# 3.4 Bulk scaling limit for one pair of characteristic polynomials 

The limiting expressions for the rescaled characteristic polynomials in the bulk can be defined in a similar way as at the edge.

Proposition 3.3 (Local limits of a pair of characteristic polynomials in the spectral bulk).
Recalling Proposition 2.1, the local scaling in the bulk, defined as

$$
z=\sqrt{d_{N}} s z_{0}+s \chi, \quad w^{*}=\sqrt{d_{N}} s z_{0}^{*}+s \eta^{*}, \quad z w^{*}=s^{2}\left(d_{N}\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}+\sqrt{2 d_{N}} y+\chi \eta^{*}\right)
$$

with $\left|z_{0}\right|<1$ and $y=\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi+z_{0} \eta^{*}\right) / \sqrt{2}$ as well as the definitions (3.1) and (3.2), leads to

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{\text {bulk }}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) & :=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} e^{-z w^{*}} \frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{A}}(0,0)}=1 \\
D_{\text {bulk }}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) & :=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} e^{-2 z w^{*}} \frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}(0,0)}=1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2} \\
D_{\text {bulk }}^{\mathrm{AII}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) & :=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} e^{-2 z w^{*}} \frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}(0,0)}=\frac{1}{1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

All three results are consistent with the respective global limit eqs. (3.6), (3.8) and (3.11) with $r=\left|z_{0}\right|$. In particular, they give unity at the origin, by setting $\left|z_{0}\right|=0$ on the right hand sides, which is consistent with their definition. This agreement and its independence of $\chi$ and $\eta^{*}$ reflect that all three ensembles satisfy locally translation invariance and isotropy as it is well-known for the three Ginibre ensembles.

Class A: Looking at (2.22), the result for the Ginibre ensemble is trivial, as the corrections to $e^{-x} E_{N}(x) \rightarrow 1$ are exponentially suppressed in this kind of large- $N$ limit.

Class $\mathbf{A I}^{\dagger}$ : Likewise, the result (2.23) for complex symmetric matrices yields for the limit (3.56)

$$
\begin{aligned}
