\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} e^{-2 z w^{*}}\left(E_{N}\left(2 z w^{*}\right)-\frac{2 z w^{*}}{N+1} E_{N-1}\left(2 z w^{*}\right)\right) & =1-\frac{N\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}+\sqrt{2 N} y+\chi \eta^{*}}{N+1} \\
& =1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}-\sqrt{\frac{2}{N}} y+\mathcal{O}(1 / N)
\end{aligned}
$$

as both truncated exponentials give unity. Evidently, the subleading term contains non-trivial information about the local spectral fluctuation $y$, that deviates from a constant behaviour.

Class $\mathbf{A I I}^{\dagger}$ : Let us turn to the ensemble of complex self-dual matrices, where we return to (3.36) determining the critical points. We note that this time the bulk scaling (3.54) is equal to $x=z w^{*}=$ $N\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}+\sqrt{N} y+\chi \eta^{*} / 2$, with $0<\left|z_{0}\right|<1$. Because of that, the maximum at $\left(u_{*}, v_{*}\right)=(0, N-x)$ (and maximum at the boundary $(0, v>0)$ ) as well the maximum $\left(u_{0}, v_{0}\right)=(2(N-x), 0)$ at the boundary $(u>0,0)$ are both inside the integration domain $u, v \geq 0$.

We need to compare the integrand in $f_{N}(x)$, see (2.63), at these two points to decide which of those is the global maximum. For this purpose, we ask for the leading asymptotic of the integrand $\exp [S(u, v)]$, with

$$
S(u, v)=-u-v+N \log \left[4 x v+(2 x+u)^{2}\right]
$$

at these two points which is

$$
e^{S\left(u_{*}, v_{*}\right)} \sim\left(2 N\left|z_{0}\right|\right)^{2 N} \exp \left[-N\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right)\right] \quad \text { and } \quad e^{S\left(u_{0}, v_{0}\right)} \sim(2 N)^{2 N} \exp \left[-2 N\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right)\right]
$$

Thus, we obtain for the difference

$$
S\left(u_{*}, v_{*}\right)-S\left(u_{0}, v_{0}\right) \sim N\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}+2 \log \left|z_{0}\right|\right)
$$

The function $h(a)=1-a+\log a$ is strictly increasing for $a=\left|z_{0}\right|^{2} \in(0,1)$ and takes its maximum at $a=1$ which is $h(1)=0$. Therefore, it is $S\left(u_{*}, v_{*}\right)<S\left(u_{0}, v_{0}\right)$ for suitable large $N$ and $\left(u_{0}, v_{0}\right)=$ $(2(N-x), 0)$ is the position of the global maximum.

Consequently, we substitute $u=2 N\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right)+2 \sqrt{N} u^{\prime}$ while the variable $v$ remains unchanged. Plugging this into the integral (3.35) we arrive at

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{N}(x)= & 2 \sqrt{N} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v \int_{-\sqrt{N}\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right)}^{\infty} d u^{\prime} e^{-2 N\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right)-2 \sqrt{N} u^{\prime}-v}\left[4 x v+\left(2 x+2 N\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right)+2 \sqrt{N} u^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right]^{N} \\
= & \frac{(2 N)^{2 N+1}}{\sqrt{N}} e^{-2 N\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right)} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v \int_{-\sqrt{N}\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right)}^{\infty} d u^{\prime} e^{-2 \sqrt{N} u^{\prime}-v}\left[1+\frac{2}{\sqrt{N}}\left(u^{\prime}+y\right)\right. \\
& \left.+\frac{1}{N}\left(v\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}+\chi \eta^{*}+\left(u^{\prime}+y\right)^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{N^{\frac{3}{2}}}\left(v y+\chi \eta^{*}\left(u^{\prime}+y\right)\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{v+\left(u^{\prime}\right)^{2}}{N^{2}}\right)\right]^{N}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, we have inserted the bulk scaling (3.54) and expanded far enough to keep the first subleading order in the final result. In the next step, we have to exponentiate the bracket to the $N$ th power, and then expand the logarithm up to third order, $\log [1+z]=z-\frac{z^{2}}{2}+\frac{z^{3}}{3}+\mathcal{O}\left(z^{4}\right)$. In addition, from the definition (3.57) we have to appropriately normalise according to (3.35). Inserting all together a lot of terms cancel, and we arrive at

$$
\begin{aligned}
e^{-2 x} \frac{f_{N}(x)}{(2 N)!}= & \frac{(2 N)^{2 N+1} e^{-2 N}}{\sqrt{N}(2 N)!} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v \int_{-\sqrt{N}\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right)}^{\infty} d u^{\prime} \exp \left[-v\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right)-\left(u^{\prime}+y\right)^{2}\right] \\
& \times\left[1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\left(v y-2\left(u^{\prime}+y\right)\left(v y+\frac{1}{2} \chi \eta^{*}-\frac{1}{3}\left(u^{\prime}+y\right)^{2}\right)\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{v^{2}+\left(u^{\prime}\right)^{4}}{N}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying the Stirling formula simplifies the prefactor to $1 / \sqrt{\pi}$ when $N \rightarrow \infty$. The error in the integral is uniform when we restrict the integration to $v^{2}+\left(u^{\prime}\right)^{4} \ll N$. As before, one can show that this does not cause any problems since the integrand is exponentially small compared to the main contribution at the origin for any choice $\varepsilon>0$ of $v+\left|u^{\prime}\right| \geq N^{\varepsilon}$, since the maximum of $S(u, v)$ in this region lies on the boundary $v+\left|u^{\prime}\right|=N^{\varepsilon}$. Therefore, Lebesgue's dominated convergence theorem is applicable.

A similar statement would also allow us to extend the integral to $-\infty$ for which we skip the rigorous mathematical details. Once done, we can exploit that all the odd moments in the Gaussian variable $u^{\prime}+y$ vanish, i.e.,

$$
e^{-2 x} \frac{f_{N}(x)}{(2 N)!}=\int_{0}^{\infty} d v \exp \left[-v\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right)\right]\left[1+\frac{v y}{\sqrt{N}}+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{v^{2}}{N}\right)\right]
$$

Here, we carried out the integral over $u^{\prime}$ yielding $\sqrt{\pi}$ up to order $1 / N$. We are left with the elementary integral over the variable $v$ which is

$$
e^{-2 x} \frac{f_{N}(x)}{(2 N)!}=\frac{1}{1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \frac{y}{\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right)^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(N^{-1}\right)
$$

This ends the derivation of the bulk limit for class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ in (3.57), including the first $y$-dependent correction term.

# 4 Expectation values for $k$ pairs of characteristic polynomials 

As the classes $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ lack the insight of an explicit joint probability density of the complex eigenvalues we need to circumvent this obstacle. The aim is to derive an effective Lagrangian representation, similar to those for real eigenvalue statistics of Hermitian random matrix ensembles. Those

were very helpful in explaining the applicability of random matrix theory to quantum field theories [68] and condensed matter theory [69].

In these applications, the main object is usually an average over products or ratios of characteristic polynomials. For instance, we consider the quantity

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{N, k}\left(Z, W^{*}\right) & :=\frac{\left\langle\prod_{j=1}^{k} \operatorname{det}\left[J-z_{j} \mathbf{1}_{d_{N}}\right] \operatorname{det}\left[J^{\dagger}-w_{j}^{*} \mathbf{1}_{d_{N}}\right]\right\rangle}{\left\langle\left|\operatorname{det}\left[J-\sqrt{d_{N}} s z_{0} \mathbf{1}_{d_{N}}\right]\right|^{2 k}\right\rangle} \\
& =\frac{\left\langle\operatorname{det}\left[J \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}-\mathbf{1}_{d_{N}} \otimes Z\right] \operatorname{det}\left[J^{\dagger} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}-\mathbf{1}_{d_{N}} \otimes W^{*}\right]\right\rangle}{\left\langle\left|\operatorname{det}\left[J \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}-\sqrt{d_{N}} s z_{0} \mathbf{1}_{d_{N}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}\right]\right|^{2}\right\rangle}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $Z=\operatorname{diag}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{k}\right)$ and $W^{*}=\operatorname{diag}\left(w_{1}^{*}, \ldots, w_{k}^{*}\right)$. We recall the definitions (3.1) and (3.2), in particular that the dimension $d_{N}$ and the scaling $s$ depend on the ensemble. We employed tensor notation to write everything in a compact form, and we normalised the expectation value to simplify the calculations below so that we can easily keep track of the normalisation constants; especially it holds $D_{N, k}\left(\sqrt{d_{N}} s z_{0} \mathbf{1}_{d_{N}}, \sqrt{d_{N}} s z_{0} \mathbf{1}_{d_{N}}\right)=1$.

In the physics literature, e.g., see $[68,69,70]$, expectation values as those in the numerator of (4.1) can be usually cast for large- $N$ into the form

$$
\left\langle\operatorname{det}\left[J \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}-\mathbf{1}_{d_{N}} \otimes Z\right] \operatorname{det}\left[J^{\dagger} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}-\mathbf{1}_{d_{N}} \otimes W^{*}\right]\right\rangle \sim C_{N} \int_{\mathcal{S}} d \mu(U) \exp \left[-\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{eff}}\left(U, Z, W^{*}\right)\right]
$$

where $C_{N}\left(Z, W^{*}\right)$ is some $N$-dependent constant, $\mathcal{S}$ is a saddle point manifold (also known as Goldstone manifold) whose size depends on $k$ but is independent of $N, d \mu(U)$ is the uniform measure on $\mathcal{S}$, and $\mathcal{L}_{\text {eff }}\left(U, Z, W^{*}\right)$ is the effective Lagrangian depending on the source variables $Z$ and $W^{*}$ as well as on $U$. The spurion analysis [70] gives some low order expansion for $\mathcal{L}_{\text {eff }}\left(U, Z, W^{*}\right)$ in terms of its arguments. We note that the set $\mathcal{S}$ as well as the Lagrangian usually depend on the points where one zooms into. In our case, this zooming is given by

$$
z_{j}=\sqrt{d_{N}} s z_{0}+s \chi_{j} \quad \text { and } \quad w_{j}^{*}=\sqrt{d_{N}} s z_{0}+s \eta_{j}^{*}
$$

with $\chi=\operatorname{diag}\left(\chi_{1}, \ldots, \chi_{k}\right)$ and $\eta=\operatorname{diag}\left(\eta_{1}, \ldots, \eta_{k}\right)$. We will indeed see that both, the saddle point manifold and the Lagrangian, change depending on whether $z_{0}$ lies in the bulk or at the spectral edge. Here, $z_{0}$ (fixed in $N$ ) is chosen to be either at the edge of the spectrum when $\left|z_{0}\right|=1$, or in the bulk of the spectrum $\left|z_{0}\right|<1$. The parameters $\chi_{j}$ and $\eta_{j}^{*}$ are also fixed and probe the spectral fluctuations on the scale of the local mean level spacing. We recall that we average over Gaussian random matrices of the form $\exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr} J J^{\dagger}\right]$ for any symmetry class. Hence, we need to adjust $d_{N}$ and $s$ for any of those.

This procedure works rather well in quantum field theory and condensed matter theory. It is also very effective for a zero-dimensional field theories which are essentially random matrix theories. We will see in the derivations of Theorems 4.1 and 4.2 that all three ensembles we consider, with the normalisation (4.1), exhibit the very same effective Lagrangian in the bulk $\left(\left|z_{0}\right|<1\right)$

$$
\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{eff}}^{\text {bulk }}\left(U, Z, W^{*}\right)=\sqrt{d_{N}} \operatorname{Tr}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi+z_{0} \eta^{*}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\operatorname{diag}(\chi, \chi) U^{\dagger} \operatorname{diag}\left(\eta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right) U\right)
$$

as well as at the edge $\left(\left|z_{0}\right|=1\right)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{eff}}^{\text {edge }}\left(A, Z, W^{*}\right)= & \sqrt{d_{N}} \operatorname{Tr}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi+z_{0} \eta^{*}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi\right)^{2}+\left(z_{0} \eta^{*}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& -\frac{z_{0}^{*}}{\sqrt{2}} \operatorname{Tr} A^{\dagger} A \operatorname{diag}(\chi, \chi)-\frac{z_{0}}{\sqrt{2}} \operatorname{Tr} A A^{\dagger} \operatorname{diag}\left(\eta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Only the saddle point manifolds are varying from ensemble to ensemble which are the most important indicator that the spectral statistics are different for the three ensembles. At the edge the set $\mathcal{S}$ is actually a vector space so that the uniform measure is the Lebesgue measure on this vector space, while in the bulk we will see that the saddle point manifolds are classical Lie groups.

We would like to emphasise that we have checked and compared with existing literature [35, 20, 36] that the real and quaternion Ginibre ensemble yield the very same Lagrangians and saddle point manifolds as the complex one (class A) when staying away from the real axis. Only when zooming in on the real axis $\mathcal{S}$ will be different from class $A$ though the Lagrangian still looks the same. We will, however, not show this here and postpone it to future work where we want to discuss all symmetry classes of non-Hermitian random matrices in this way.

Coming back to the three ensembles we discuss here, we would like to remark that the normalisation with respect to the denominator of (4.1) helps to keep track of the normalisation though it is not enough to have a well-defined limit $N \rightarrow \infty$. This can be seen in the resulting Lagrangians (4.4) and (4.5), due to the $d_{N}$-dependent term. To take care of that we normalise the ratio as follows

$$
\widehat{D}_{N, k}\left(Z, W^{*}\right):=\frac{D_{N, k}\left(Z, W^{*}\right)}{\prod_{j=1}^{k} D_{N, 1}\left(z_{j}, w_{j}^{*}\right)}
$$

The pairings into arguments $\left(z_{j}, w_{j}^{*}\right)$ in the product of expectation values in the denominator is introduced ad hoc but becomes natural when choosing $w_{j}^{*}=z_{j}^{*}$. The latter choice gives the source variables an interpretation of some complex conjugate pairs of "test-charges" that explore the spectrum of the random matrix $J$.

# 4.1 Bulk limit for $k>1$ pairs of characteristic polynomials 

Theorem 4.1 (Bulk limit for $k>1$ ).
We recall the definitions (4.1) and (4.6). In the bulk limit (4.3) with $\left|z_{0}\right|<1$ we obtain the following expressions for

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{\text {bulk }, k}^{\mathrm{R}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) & :=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \widehat{D}_{N, k}^{\mathrm{R}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right) \\
& =\exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr} \chi \eta^{*}\right] \int_{\mathcal{G}} d \mu(U) \exp \left[\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\operatorname{diag}(\chi, \chi) U^{\dagger} \operatorname{diag}\left(\eta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right) U\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

In all three cases, the saddle point manifolds are Lie groups given by $\mathcal{G}=\mathrm{U}(k)$ for class $R=A$ (complex Ginibre), $\mathcal{G}=\operatorname{USp}(2 k)$ for class $R=A I^{\dagger}$ (complex symmetric), and $\mathcal{G}=\mathrm{O}(2 k)$ for class $R=A I I^{\dagger}$ (complex self-dual), where $d \mu(U)$ is their normalised Haar measure. For class $A$, we embed $\mathrm{U}(k)$ into the $2 k \times 2 k$ matrices as follows, $U=\operatorname{diag}(\widetilde{U}, \widetilde{U})$ with $\widetilde{U} \in \mathrm{U}(k)$, to write the result for all three classes in a unifying way.

The expression (4.7) is translation and rotation invariant, particularly it is

$$
D_{\text {bulk }, k}^{\mathrm{R}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right)=D_{\text {bulk }, k}^{\mathrm{R}}\left(e^{i \vartheta} \chi+\lambda \mathbf{1}_{k}, e^{-i \vartheta} \eta^{*}+\lambda^{*} \mathbf{1}_{k}\right)
$$

for any fixed $\vartheta \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}$. As aforementioned, this is one of the main features of a bulk point. Actually the symmetry group is even larger in this particular case as the invariance even holds for $\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) \rightarrow\left(e^{i \vartheta} \chi+\lambda \mathbf{1}_{k}, e^{-i \vartheta} \eta^{*}+\mu^{*} \mathbf{1}_{k}\right)$ for any $\vartheta, \lambda, \mu \in \mathbb{C}$. This is due to the analyticity in both arguments, $\chi$ and $\eta^{*}$, individually.

The result (4.7) for class A was previously derived in [54, Theorem 1.15]. It was shown in [53] that away from the real axis the same result prevails for the real and quaternion Ginibre ensemble. We

have checked this statement independently using the same technique as below. The group integral is actually the Harish-Chandra-Itzykson-Zuber integral [71, 59] which is explicitly known

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{\text {bulk }, k}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) & =\exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr} \chi \eta^{*}\right] \int_{\mathrm{U}(k)} d \mu(U) \exp \left[\operatorname{Tr}\left(\chi \widetilde{U}^{\dagger} \eta^{*} \widetilde{U}\right)\right] \\
& =\left(\prod_{j=0}^{k-1} j!\right) \frac{\exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr} \chi \eta^{*}\right]}{\Delta_{k}(\chi) \Delta_{k}\left(\eta^{*}\right)} \operatorname{det}\left[\exp \left(\chi_{a} \eta_{b}^{*}\right)\right]_{a, b=1, \ldots, k}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\Delta_{k}(x)=\prod_{1 \leq a<b \leq k}\left(x_{b}-x_{a}\right)
$$

is the Vandermonde determinant. This agrees with a derivation based on planar orthogonal polynomials presented in Appendix B.

The group integrals in (4.7) for $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ are the other two Itzykson-Zuber integrals [59] which are not known explicitly, and only recurrence relations exist [72]. In particular, the authors observed that the recurrence relations are incompatible with determinantal or Pfaffian structures.

Class A: We start with the derivation for the complex Ginibre ensemble, in order to be selfcontained. Let us recall that it is $d_{N}=N$ and $s=1$ in this case.

To deal with the characteristic polynomials in (4.1) we introduce two $N \times k$ dimensional complex Grassmann matrices

$$
\xi=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
\xi_{11} & \cdots & \xi_{1 k} \\
\vdots & & \vdots \\
\xi_{N 1} & \cdots & \xi_{N k}
\end{array}\right] \quad \text { and } \quad \psi=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
\psi_{11} & \cdots & \psi_{1 k} \\
\vdots & & \vdots \\
\psi_{N 1} & \cdots & \psi_{N k}
\end{array}\right]
$$

via the standard identity

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{det}\left[J \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}-\mathbf{1}_{N} \otimes Z\right] \operatorname{det}\left[J^{\dagger} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}-\mathbf{1}_{N} \otimes W^{*}\right] \\
= & \int[d \xi][d \psi] \exp \left[\operatorname{Tr} J \xi \xi^{\dagger}+\operatorname{Tr} J^{\dagger} \psi \psi^{\dagger}+\operatorname{Tr} Z \xi^{\dagger} \xi+\operatorname{Tr} W^{*} \psi^{\dagger} \psi\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

with $[d \xi][d \psi]=\prod_{l=1}^{N} \prod_{j=1}^{k} d \xi_{l j} d \xi_{l j}^{*} d \psi_{l j} d \psi_{l j}^{*}$ and $\psi^{\dagger}$ being the transpose and complex conjugate of $\psi_{l}$ which is the generalisation of (2.12). We would like to underline that we have exploited the anticommutation relations of Grassmann variables when interchanging the matrices $\psi$ and $\psi^{\dagger}$. For the determinant in the denominator in (4.1) we only need to set $\chi_{j}=\eta_{j}=0$ in the above expression.

For the complex Ginibre ensemble the matrix $J$ does not satisfy any symmetries so that we can take the expectation of it without further ado,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& D_{N, k}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right)= \\
= & \frac{\int[d \xi][d \psi] \exp \left[\operatorname{Tr} \xi \xi^{\dagger} \psi \psi^{\dagger}+\operatorname{Tr} Z \xi^{\dagger} \xi+\operatorname{Tr} W^{*} \psi^{\dagger} \psi\right]}{\int[d \xi][d \psi] \exp \left[\operatorname{Tr} \xi \xi^{\dagger} \psi \psi^{\dagger}+\sqrt{N} z_{0} \operatorname{Tr} \xi^{\dagger} \xi+\sqrt{N} z_{0}^{*} \operatorname{Tr} \psi^{\dagger} \psi\right]} \\
= & \frac{\int[d \xi][d \psi] \int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d A] \exp \left[-N \operatorname{Tr} A^{\dagger} A+i \sqrt{N} \operatorname{Tr} A \psi^{\dagger} \xi+i \sqrt{N} \operatorname{Tr} A^{\dagger} \xi^{\dagger} \psi+\operatorname{Tr} Z \xi^{\dagger} \xi+\operatorname{Tr} W^{*} \psi^{\dagger} \psi\right]}{\int[d \xi][d \psi] \int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d A] \exp \left[-N \operatorname{Tr} A^{\dagger} A+i \sqrt{N} \operatorname{Tr} A \psi^{\dagger} \xi+i \sqrt{N} \operatorname{Tr} A^{\dagger} \xi^{\dagger} \psi+\sqrt{N} z_{0} \operatorname{Tr} \xi^{\dagger} \xi+\sqrt{N} z_{0}^{*} \operatorname{Tr} \psi^{\dagger} \psi\right]}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used the anti-commutativity of the Grassmann variables and applied the Hubbard-Stratonovich transformation [73] in the second equality. The linearisation in the dyadic matrices $\psi^{\dagger} \xi$ and $\xi^{\dagger} \psi$ allows

us to integrate over all Grassmann variables again as they are simple Gaussians, i.e.,

$$
\int[d \xi][d \psi] \exp \left[i \sqrt{N} \operatorname{Tr} A \psi^{\dagger} \xi+i \sqrt{N} \operatorname{Tr} A^{\dagger} \xi^{\dagger} \psi+\operatorname{Tr} Z \xi^{\dagger} \xi+\operatorname{Tr} W^{*} \psi^{\dagger} \psi\right]=\operatorname{det}\left[\begin{array}{cc}
Z & i \sqrt{N} A^{\dagger} \\
i \sqrt{N} A & W^{*}
\end{array}\right]^{N}
$$

which leads to

$$
D_{N, k}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right)=\frac{\int_{\mathcal{C}^{k \times k}}[d A] \exp \left[-N \operatorname{Tr} A^{\dagger} A\right] \operatorname{det}\left[Z W^{*} / N+A^{\dagger}\left(W^{*}\right)^{-1} A W^{*}\right]^{N}}{\int_{\mathcal{C}^{k \times k}}[d A] \exp \left[-N \operatorname{Tr} A^{\dagger} A\right] \operatorname{det}\left[\left|z_{0}\right|^{2} \mathbf{1}_{k}+A^{\dagger} A\right]^{N}}
$$

To simplify the determinant we have exploited (2.39).
When taking the large- $N$ limit, we need to maximise the leading order Lagrangian

$$
\mathcal{L}=-\operatorname{Tr} A^{\dagger} A+\operatorname{Tr} \log \left(\left|z_{0}\right|^{2} \mathbf{1}_{k}+A^{\dagger} A\right)
$$

in $A$. This is evidently uniquely given when

$$
A^{\dagger} A=\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right) \mathbf{1}_{k}
$$

which follows from differentiating $\mathcal{L}$ in $A^{\dagger} A$.
We expand about this solution by first going over to the polar decomposition $A=\widetilde{U} H$ with $\widetilde{U} \in \mathrm{U}(k)$ a unitary matrix and $H=H^{\dagger} \geq 0$ a positive semi-definite matrix. The measure transforms (up to a normalisation) as follows

$$
[d A] \propto \operatorname{det}\left(H \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}+\mathbf{1}_{k} \otimes H\right)[d H] d \widetilde{\mu}(\widetilde{U})
$$

where $d \widetilde{\mu}(\widetilde{U})$ is the normalised Haar measure on $\mathrm{U}(k)$. The Jacobian can be computed by performing first a singular value decomposition of $A$ and then reverse the eigenvalue decomposition of $H$. In this way, the term $\operatorname{det}\left(H \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}+\mathbf{1}_{k} \otimes H\right)$ is reminiscent of the fact that the singular value decomposition yields a square of a Vandermonde determinant in the squared singular values of $A$ as well as a factor $\operatorname{det} H$. The singular values are, however, the eigenvalues of $H$ whose eigenvalue decomposition only needs a square of a Vandermonde determinant in the eigenvalues, and not their squares which is corrected by the non-trivial term $\operatorname{det}\left(H \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}+\mathbf{1}_{k} \otimes H\right)$.

After this transformation we set $H=\sqrt{1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}} \mathbf{1}_{k}+\delta H / \sqrt{N}$ and expand in $1 / \sqrt{N}$, showing that the term $\operatorname{det}\left(H \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}+\mathbf{1}_{k} \otimes H\right)$ only yields a constant in leading order. For the determinant, we use

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{det}\left[\frac{Z W^{*}}{N}+A^{\dagger}\left(W^{*}\right)^{-1} A W^{*}\right] & =\operatorname{det}\left[\begin{array}{cc}
z_{0} \mathbf{1}_{k}+\frac{\chi}{\sqrt{N}} & \left(\sqrt{1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}} \mathbf{1}_{k}+\frac{\delta H}{\sqrt{N}}\right) \widetilde{U}^{\dagger} \\
-\widetilde{U}\left(\sqrt{1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}} \mathbf{1}_{k}+\frac{\delta H}{\sqrt{N}}\right) & z_{0}^{*} \mathbf{1}_{k}+\frac{\eta^{*}}{\sqrt{N}} \\
=\operatorname{det}\left[\mathbf{1}_{2 k}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\left[\begin{array}{cc}
z_{0}^{*} \mathbf{1}_{k} & -\sqrt{1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}} \widetilde{U}^{\dagger} \\
\sqrt{1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}} \widetilde{U}^{\dagger} & z_{0} \mathbf{1}_{k}
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{cc}
\chi & \delta H \widetilde{U}^{\dagger} \\
-\widetilde{U} \delta H & \eta^{*}
\end{array}\right]\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

which can be found by going back to the structure to the determinant in (4.14) with the matrix in its block form. This leads to the expansion

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \exp \left[-N \operatorname{Tr} A^{\dagger} A\right] \operatorname{det}\left[\frac{Z W^{*}}{N}+A^{\dagger}\left(W^{*}\right)^{-1} A W^{*}\right]^{N} \\
= & \exp \left[-N k\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right)+\sqrt{N} \operatorname{Tr}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi+z_{0} \eta^{*}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi\right)^{2}+\left(z_{0} \eta^{*}\right)^{2}-2\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right) \chi \widetilde{U}^{\dagger} \eta^{*} \widetilde{U}\right]\right. \\
& \left.-2\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right) \operatorname{Tr} \delta H^{2}-2 \sqrt{1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}} \operatorname{Tr} \delta H\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi+z_{0} \widetilde{U}^{\dagger} \eta^{*} \widetilde{U}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\|\delta H\|^{3}}{\sqrt{N}}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\|X\|=\sqrt{\operatorname{Tr} X X^{\dagger}}$ is the Hilbert-Schmidt norm of a matrix. This highlights that we obtain a Gaussian approximation in $\delta H$ uniformly when $\|\delta H\| \ll N^{1 / 6}$. One can, however, show that the integral restricted to $\|\delta H\| \gg N^{\varepsilon}$ for any fixed $\varepsilon>0$ is exponentially small compared to the main contribution at $\delta H=0$ so that a restriction to say $\|\delta H\| \leq N^{1 / 12}$ is sufficient. We will not work out these mathematical details as they do not illuminate the problem further.

The Gaussian integral in $\delta H$ we obtain after these expansions are integrated out and we arrive at

$$
D_{N, k}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right)=\exp \left[\sqrt{N} \operatorname{Tr}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi+z_{0} \eta^{*}\right)\right] \int_{\mathrm{U}(k)} d \tilde{\mu}(\widetilde{U}) \exp \left[\operatorname{Tr}\left(\chi \widetilde{U}^{\dagger} \eta^{*} \widetilde{U}\right)\right]\left[1+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)\right]
$$

We note that for $k=1$ it is trivially

$$
\prod_{l=1}^{k} D_{N, 1}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(z_{l}, w_{l}^{*}\right) \sim \exp \left[\sqrt{N} \sum_{j=1}^{k}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{j}+z_{0} \eta_{j}^{*}\right)\right] \exp \left[\sum_{l=1}^{k} \chi_{l} \eta_{l}^{*}\right]
$$

which shows how the exponential prefactor comes about for class $A$. Finally, we bring it into the unifying form (4.7) by choosing $U=\operatorname{diag}(\widetilde{U}, \widetilde{U})$ and $d \mu(U)=d \tilde{\mu}(\widetilde{U})$.

Classes $\mathbf{A I}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathbf{A I I}^{\dagger}$ : We turn to the complex symmetric and complex self-dual random matrices which can be dealt with in parallel. We recall that the scaling is for both ensembles $s=1 / 2$ while the dimension is $d_{N}=N$ for class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $d_{N}=2 N$ for class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$. Their corresponding symmetry can be written in a unifying form $J^{T}=T J T$, with

$$
T=\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
\mathbf{1}_{N}, & J \text { is symmetric, } \quad d_{N}=N, \quad \text { class } \mathrm{R}=\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger} \\
\tau_{2} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{N}=\Sigma_{y}, & J \text { is self-dual, } \quad d_{N}=2 N, \quad \text { class } \mathrm{R}=\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $\tau_{2}$ is the second Pauli matrix. This matrix has a dual one of the form

$$
\hat{T}=\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
\tau_{2} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}, & J \text { is symmetric, } \quad \text { class } \mathrm{R}=\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger} \\
\mathbf{1}_{2 k}, & J \text { is self-dual, } \quad \text { class } \mathrm{R}=\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}
\end{array}\right.
$$

which are both of dimension $2 k$. Using these two matrices, we may rewrite the determinants in terms of Pfaffians

$$
\operatorname{det}\left[J \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}-\mathbf{1}_{d_{N}} \otimes Z\right] \operatorname{det}\left[J^{\dagger} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{k}-\mathbf{1}_{d_{N}} \otimes W^{*}\right]= \pm \operatorname{Pf}[T J \otimes \hat{T}-T \otimes \tilde{z} \hat{T}] \operatorname{Pf}\left[T J^{\dagger} \otimes \hat{T}-T \otimes \tilde{w} \hat{T}\right]
$$

with $\tilde{z}=\operatorname{diag}(Z, Z)$ and $\tilde{w}=\operatorname{diag}\left(W^{*}, W^{*}\right)$. The overall sign is, however, not a problem as it is cancelled in the ratio (4.1). The two Pfaffians can be expressed as Gaussian integrals over two $d_{N} \times 2 k$ real Grassmann matrices

$$
\xi=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
\xi_{11} & \cdots & \xi_{12 k} \\
\vdots & & \vdots \\
\xi_{d_{N} 1} & \cdots & \xi_{d_{N} 2 k}
\end{array}\right] \quad \text { and } \quad \psi=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
\psi_{11} & \cdots & \psi_{12 k} \\
\vdots & & \vdots \\
\psi_{d_{N} 1} & \cdots & \psi_{d_{N} 2 k}
\end{array}\right]
$$

similar to (2.13), namely

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Pf}[T J \otimes \hat{T}-T \otimes \tilde{z} \hat{T}] \operatorname{Pf}\left[T J^{\dagger} \otimes \hat{T}-T \otimes \tilde{w} \hat{T}\right] \\
= & \int[d \xi][d \psi] \exp \left[\operatorname{Tr} T J \xi \hat{T} \xi^{T}+\operatorname{Tr} T J^{\dagger} \psi \hat{T} \psi^{T}+\operatorname{Tr} \xi^{T} T \xi \tilde{z} \hat{T}+\operatorname{Tr} \psi^{T} T \psi \tilde{w} \hat{T}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Let the superscript R be either $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ or $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ to point out the ensemble in the ensuing computation. Once we carry out the Gaussian average over $J$ we arrive at

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{N, k}^{\mathrm{R}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right) & =\frac{\int[d \xi][d \psi] \exp \left[\operatorname{Tr} \xi \hat{T} \xi^{T} T \psi \hat{T} \psi^{T} T+\operatorname{Tr} \xi^{T} T \xi \bar{z} \hat{T}+\operatorname{Tr} \psi^{T} T \psi \bar{w} \hat{T}\right]}{\int[d \xi][d \psi] \exp \left[\operatorname{Tr} \xi \hat{T} \xi^{T} T \psi \hat{T} \psi^{T} T+\sqrt{\frac{d_{N}}{2}} z_{0} \operatorname{Tr} \xi^{T} T \xi \hat{T}+\sqrt{\frac{d_{N}}{2}} z_{0}^{*} \operatorname{Tr} \psi^{T} T \psi \hat{T}\right]} \\
& =\frac{\int[d \xi][d \psi] \int_{\mathcal{M}}[d A] \exp \left[\overline{\mathcal{L}}(A, \xi, \psi, \bar{z}, \bar{w})\right]}{\int[d \xi][d \psi] \int_{\mathcal{M}}[d A] \exp \left[\overline{\mathcal{L}}\left(A, \xi, \psi, z_{0} \mathbf{1}_{2 k}, z_{0}^{*} \mathbf{1}_{2 k}\right)\right]}
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\overline{\mathcal{L}}(A, \xi, \psi, \bar{z}, \bar{w})=-\frac{d_{N}}{2} \operatorname{Tr} A A^{\dagger}+i \sqrt{\frac{d_{N}}{2}}\left(\operatorname{Tr} A \hat{T} \psi^{T} T \xi+\operatorname{Tr} A^{T} \xi^{T} T \psi \hat{T}\right)+\operatorname{Tr} \xi^{T} T \xi \bar{z} \hat{T}+\operatorname{Tr} \psi^{T} T \psi \bar{w} \hat{T}
$$

The Hubbard-Stratonovich transformation has been carried out with the help of the set $\mathcal{M}$ of $2 k \times 2 k$ quaternion (if $J$ has been symmetric) or real (if $J$ has been self-dual) matrices $A$. The different matrix spaces come into play as we need the property $A^{*}=\hat{T} A \hat{T}$ to guarantee an integrable Gaussian in $A$ where the completion of squares, especially the shift $A \rightarrow A+i \sqrt{\frac{2}{d_{N}}} \xi^{T} T \psi \hat{T}$, works out.

The integrals over $\xi$ and $\psi$ are again a Pfaffian determinant,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int[d \xi][d \psi] \exp \left[i \sqrt{\frac{d_{N}}{2}}\left(\operatorname{Tr} A \hat{T} \psi^{T} T \xi+\operatorname{Tr} A^{T} \xi^{T} T \psi \hat{T}\right)+\operatorname{Tr} \xi^{T} T \xi \bar{z} \hat{T}+\operatorname{Tr} \psi^{T} T \psi \bar{w} \hat{T}\right] \\
=\operatorname{Pf}\left[\begin{array}{cc}
T \otimes \bar{z} \hat{T} & i \sqrt{\frac{d_{N}}{2}} T \otimes \hat{T} A^{T} \\
i \sqrt{\frac{d_{N}}{2}} T \otimes A \hat{T} & T \otimes \bar{w} \hat{T}
\end{array}\right]=\operatorname{det}\left[\bar{z} \bar{w}+\frac{d_{N}}{2} A^{\dagger} \bar{w}^{-1} A \bar{w}\right]^{d_{N} / 2}
\end{gathered}
$$

The square root of the determinant is chosen such that the sign agrees with the Pfaffian. The root is actually not a problem for the class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ since $d_{N}=2 N$ is even so that no root is taken. In contrast, for class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ we understand the analytic structure of the right hand side in terms of the left hand side which is evidently a polynomial of the matrix entries.

Let us summarise so far. The ratio of averages is with the above input equals to

$$
D_{N, k}^{\mathrm{R}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right)=\frac{\int_{\mathcal{M}}[d A] \exp \left[-\frac{d_{N}}{2} \operatorname{Tr} A A^{\dagger}\right] \operatorname{det}\left[\frac{2}{d_{N}} \bar{z} \bar{w}+A^{\dagger} \bar{w}^{-1} A \bar{w}\right]^{d_{N} / 2}}{\int_{\mathcal{M}}[d A] \exp \left[-\frac{d_{N}}{2} \operatorname{Tr} A A^{\dagger}\right] \operatorname{det}\left[\left|z_{0}\right|^{2} \mathbf{1}_{2 k}+A^{\dagger} A\right]^{d_{N} / 2}}
$$

This duality formula for classes $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ for $k>1$ was derived independently in [41].
To take the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$, we follow the ideas of class A and need to maximise the leading order of the Lagrangian

$$
\mathcal{L}=-\operatorname{Tr} A^{\dagger} A+\operatorname{Tr} \log \left(\left|z_{0}\right|^{2} \mathbf{1}_{2 k}+A^{\dagger} A\right)
$$

The only difference to the complex Ginibre ensemble is that now $A$ is not complex but quaternion or real, respectively.

Like in class A, the variation of $\mathcal{L}$ in $A^{\dagger} A$ gives the unique solution $A^{\dagger} A=\left(1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}\right) \mathbf{1}_{2 k}$ so that a reasonable expansion could be done with the help of the substitution

$$
A=U\left(\sqrt{1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}} \mathbf{1}_{2 k}+\sqrt{\frac{2}{d_{N}}} \delta H\right)
$$

Here, we made use of the polar decomposition for quaternion and real matrices, i.e., $U \in \operatorname{USp}(2 k)$ is unitary symplectic and $\delta H \in \operatorname{Self}(2 k)$ is quaternion self-dual when $J$ has been complex symmetric (class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ ), and $U \in \mathrm{O}(2 k)$ is orthogonal and $\delta H \in \operatorname{Sym}(2 k)$ is real symmetric when $J$ has been complex self-dual (class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ ). Apart from the different matrix spaces, the analysis is completely analogous to class A, and we eventually arrive at

$$
D_{N, k}^{\mathrm{R}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right)=e^{\sqrt{d_{N}} \operatorname{Tr}\left\{z_{0}^{*} \chi+z_{0} \eta^{*}\right\}} \int_{\mathcal{G}} d \mu(U) \exp \left[\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\operatorname{diag}(\chi, \chi) U^{\dagger} \operatorname{diag}\left(\eta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right) U\right)\right]\left[1+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)\right]
$$

with the group $\mathcal{G}=\operatorname{USp}(2 k)$ (class $\left.\mathrm{R}=\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}\right)$ or $\mathcal{G}=\mathrm{O}(2 k)$ (class $\left.\mathrm{R}=\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}\right)$. This also concludes the proof for these two classes.

# 4.2 Edge limit for $k>1$ pairs of characteristic polynomials 

Theorem 4.2 (Edge limit for $k>1$ ).
In the edge limit (4.3) with $\left|z_{0}\right|=1$ we obtain the following expression

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{\text {edge }, k}^{\mathrm{R}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right): & =\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \widetilde{D}_{N, k}^{\mathrm{R}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right) \\
& =\frac{\int_{\mathcal{M}}[d A] \exp \left[-\frac{z_{0}^{*}}{\sqrt{2}} \operatorname{Tr} A^{\dagger} A \operatorname{diag}(\chi, \chi)-\frac{z_{0}}{\sqrt{2}} \operatorname{Tr} A A^{\dagger} \operatorname{diag}\left(\eta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2}\right]}{\widetilde{Z}_{k}^{\mathrm{R}} \prod_{j=1}^{k} \exp \left[\frac{\left[z_{0}^{*} \chi_{j}+z_{0} \eta_{j}^{*}\right)^{2}}{2}\right] D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{R}}\left(\chi_{j}, \eta_{j}^{*}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we recall the definitions (4.1) and (4.6), the double scaling (4.3), and the results for the average of a pair of characteristic polynomials at the edge in Theorem 3.2. The saddle manifold $\mathcal{M}$ is the set of complex $k \times k$ matrices $\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}$ (class $R=A$ ), quaternion $2 k \times 2 k$ matrices $\mathbb{H}^{k \times k}$ (class $R=A I^{\dagger}$ ), and real $2 k \times 2 k$ matrices $\mathbb{R}^{2 k \times 2 k}$ (class $R=A I I^{\dagger}$ ). All three sets are equipped with their corresponding Lebesgue measure $[d A]$. Similar to the bulk statistics, we have embedded the complex $k \times k$ matrices in the $2 k \times 2 k$ matrices, $A=\operatorname{diag}(\widetilde{A}, \widetilde{A})$ with $\widetilde{A} \in \mathbb{C}^{k \times k}$, to have a unifying result (4.35) for all three ensembles. The normalisation constants are for the

1. complex Ginibre ensemble (class $A$ ):

$$
\widetilde{Z}_{k}^{\mathrm{A}}:=\frac{\int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right)^{2}\right]}{\left[D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{A}}(0,0)\right]^{k}}=\frac{\pi^{k^{2}}}{\prod_{j=0}^{k-1}(j!)^{2}} \operatorname{det}\left[\Gamma\left(\frac{a+b-1}{2}\right)\right]_{a, b=1, \ldots, k}
$$

2. complex symmetric random matrices (class $A I^{\dagger}$ ):

$$
\widetilde{Z}_{k}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}:=\frac{\int_{\mathbb{H}^{k \times k}}[d A] \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2}\right]}{\left[D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}(0,0)\right]^{k}}=\frac{\pi^{2 k^{2}}(\pi / 2)^{k / 2}}{\prod_{j=0}^{k-1}[(2 j+1)!]^{2}} \operatorname{Pf}\left[(b-a) \Gamma\left(\frac{a+b-1}{2}\right)\right]_{a, b=1, \ldots, 2 k}
$$

3. complex self-dual random matrices (class $A I I^{\dagger}$ ):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{Z}_{k}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}} & :=\frac{\int_{\mathbb{R}^{2 k \times 2 k}}[d A] \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2}\right]}{\left[D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}}(0,0)\right]^{k}} \\
& =\left(\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2^{5 / 4} \operatorname{arccoth}(\sqrt{2})}\right)^{k} \frac{(2 \pi)^{2 k^{2}}}{\prod_{j=0}^{k-1}[(2 j)!]^{2}} \\
& \times \operatorname{Pf}\left[\left(\frac{2^{b / 2}}{2 a-1} 2 F_{1}\left[\frac{5-2 b}{4}, \frac{2 a-1}{4} ; \frac{2 a+3}{4} ; \frac{1}{2}\right]-\frac{2^{a / 2}}{2 b-1} 2 F_{1}\left[\frac{5-2 a}{4}, \frac{2 b-1}{4} ; \frac{2 b+3}{4} ; \frac{1}{2}\right]\right) \Gamma\left(\frac{a+b-1}{2}\right)\right]_{a, b=1, \ldots, 2 k}
\end{aligned}
$$

where ${ }_{2} F_{1}$ is Gauss hypergeometric function.
Anew, there is a translation invariance though only parallel to the boundary, meaning

$$
D_{\text {edge }, k}^{\mathrm{R}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right)=D_{\text {edge }, k}^{\mathrm{R}}\left(\chi+\lambda z_{0}, \eta^{*}-\lambda z_{0}^{*}\right)
$$

for an arbitrary $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}$. It only says that we can shift the point we are zooming into parallel to the boundary without changing the statistics. This symmetry is like in the bulk enhanced to $\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right) \rightarrow$ $\left(\chi+\lambda z_{0}, \eta^{*}-\lambda z_{0}^{*}\right)$ with a complex $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}$ since there is an independent analyticity in $\chi$ and $\eta^{*}$.

The result for the complex Ginibre ensemble (class A) is again known, see [54, Theorem 1.14]. Like for the bulk, the corresponding integral

$$
D_{\text {edge }, k}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right)=\frac{\int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A} \chi-\sqrt{2} z_{0} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \eta^{*}-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right)^{2}\right]}{\widetilde{Z}_{k}^{\mathrm{A}} \prod_{j=1}^{k} \exp \left[\frac{\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{j}+z_{0} \eta_{j}^{*}\right)^{2}}{2}\right] D_{\text {edge }}\left(\chi_{j}, \eta_{j}^{*}\right)}
$$

can be carried out as it is related to a deformation of a Wishart ensemble. The result is

$$
D_{\text {edge }, k}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(\chi, \eta^{*}\right)=\frac{\left(\prod_{j=0}^{k-1} 2^{-j} \sqrt{\pi}(j!)^{2}\right)}{\operatorname{det}[\Gamma([a+b-1] / 2)]_{a, b=1, \ldots, k}} \frac{\operatorname{det}\left[\operatorname{erfc}\left[\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{a}+z_{0} \eta_{b}^{*}\right) / \sqrt{2}\right] e^{\chi_{a} \eta_{b}^{*}}\right]_{a, b=1, \ldots, k}}{\Delta_{k}(\chi) \Delta_{k}\left(\eta^{*}\right) \prod_{j=1}^{k} \operatorname{erfc}\left[\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{j}+z_{0} \eta_{j}^{*}\right) / \sqrt{2}\right] e^{\chi_{j} \eta_{j}^{*}}}
$$

It is compared to the derivation using orthogonal polynomials in Appendix B. We present the derivation of the results for class A to be self-consistent and to prepare for the other two symmetry classes.

Class A: We anew begin with the derivation for the complex Ginibre ensemble and can even start with (4.15) where $z_{0}$ is now a complex phase, i.e., $\left|z_{0}\right|=1$. The expansion is much simpler than in the bulk as the Lagrangian (4.16), which is still the same, takes its maximum at the origin in the current situation. Therefore, we only rescale as follows $A=(2 / N)^{1 / 4} \widetilde{A}$ and, then, expand the determinant

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{det}\left[\frac{Z W^{*}}{N}+\sqrt{\frac{2}{N}} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger}\left(w^{*}\right)^{-1} \widetilde{A} w^{*}\right]^{N}=\operatorname{det}\left(\mathbf{1}_{2 k}+\left[\begin{array}{cc}
N^{-1 / 2} z_{0}^{*} \chi & (2 / N)^{1 / 4} z_{0}^{*} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \\
-(2 / N)^{1 / 4} z_{0} \widetilde{A} & N^{-1 / 2} z_{0} \eta^{*}
\end{array}\right]\right)^{N} \\
& =\exp \left[\sqrt{N} \operatorname{Tr}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi+z_{0} \eta^{*}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi\right)^{2}+\left(z_{0} \eta^{*}\right)^{2}\right]+\sqrt{2 N} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right. \\
& \left.-\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A} \chi-\sqrt{2} z_{0} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \eta^{*}-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right)^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\left\|\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right\|^{3}}{\sqrt{N}}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The error shows that it becomes uniform when assuming a cut-off for the integral so that $\left\|\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right\| \ll$ $N^{1 / 6}$. Like before this can be done as the integrand is exponentially suppressed compared to its maximal contribution at the origin whenever $\left\|\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right\| \geq N^{\varepsilon}$ for any fixed $\varepsilon>0$ so that Lebesgue's dominated convergence theorem can be applied. We omit the mathematical details here but only want to say that the maximum of the integrand in the region can be estimated at $\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}=N^{\varepsilon} \mathbf{1}_{k}$.

Plugging the expansion (4.42) into (4.15) leads to

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{N, k}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right)= & \exp \left[\sqrt{N} \operatorname{Tr}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi+z_{0} \eta^{*}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi\right)^{2}+\left(z_{0} \eta^{*}\right)^{2}\right]\right] \\
& \times \frac{\int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A} \chi-\sqrt{2} z_{0} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \eta^{*}-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right)^{2}\right]}{\int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right)^{2}\right]} \int_{1}+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Exploiting the result (3.23) and dividing (4.43) by the product $\prod_{j=1}^{k} D_{\text {edge }}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(z_{j}, w_{j}^{*}\right)$ we find the claim up to the normalisation constant. We underline that we have doubled the matrix dimension by the embedding $A=\operatorname{diag}(\widetilde{A}, \widetilde{A})$ and set $[d A]=[d \widetilde{A}]$, we abuse the notation and call the new matrix again $A$ to write the formula in a unifying way with the other two ensembles.

Normalisation of Class A: We can compute the normalisation (4.36) by using (3.29) and computing the integral

$$
\int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right)^{2}\right]=\int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right)\right] \frac{\int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right)^{2}\right]}{\int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right)\right]}
$$

The extension of the fraction by the Gaussian integral allows us to perform the singular value decomposition $\widetilde{A}=U \sqrt{S} V^{\dagger}$ with $U, V \in \mathrm{U}(k)$ and $S=\operatorname{diag}\left(s_{1}, \ldots, s_{k}\right) \geq 1$, without worrying about the normalisation while the Gaussian prefactor can be readily computed,

$$
\int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right)^{2}\right]=\pi^{k^{2}} \frac{\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{k}}[d S]\left|\Delta_{k}(S)\right|^{2} \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr} S^{2}\right]}{\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{k}}[d S]\left|\Delta_{k}(S)\right|^{2} \exp [-\operatorname{Tr} S]}
$$

The integral in the denominator is a Selberg integral given in [74, Eq. (17.6.5)], and the numerator can be simplified with the help of Andréief's integral indentity [75] (sometimes also called Cauchy-Binet integral formula) so that we arrive at

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right)^{2}\right] & =\frac{\pi^{k^{2}}}{\prod_{j=0}^{k-1}(j!)^{2}} \operatorname{det}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} d s s^{a+b-2} e^{-s^{2}}\right]_{a, b=1, \ldots, k} \\
& =\frac{\pi^{k^{2}}}{2^{k} \prod_{j=0}^{k-1}(j!)^{2}} \operatorname{det}\left[\Gamma\left(\frac{a+b-1}{2}\right)\right]_{a, b=1, \ldots, k}
\end{aligned}
$$

When combining this with the factor $2^{k}$ from (3.29) we find (4.36).
Yet, the integral in the numerator of (4.40) can be carried out where we employ the same trick as for the normalisation constant

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A} \chi-\sqrt{2} z_{0} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \eta^{*}-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right)^{2}\right] \\
= & \int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A} \chi-\sqrt{2} z_{0} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \eta^{*}\right] \\
& \times \frac{\int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A} \chi-\sqrt{2} z_{0} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \eta^{*}-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A}\right)^{2}\right]}{\int_{\mathbb{C}^{k \times k}}[d \widetilde{A}] \exp \left[-\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \widetilde{A} \chi-\sqrt{2} z_{0} \operatorname{Tr} \widetilde{A} \widetilde{A}^{\dagger} \eta^{*}\right]} \\
= & \frac{\pi^{k^{2}}}{\prod_{a, b=1}^{k}\left(\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \chi_{a}+\sqrt{2} z_{0} \eta_{b}^{*}\right)} \\
& \times \frac{\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{k}}[d S] \int_{\mathrm{U}(k)^{2}} d \mu(U) d \mu(V)\left|\Delta_{k}(S)\right|^{2} \exp \left[-\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \operatorname{Tr}\left(V^{\dagger} S V \chi\right)-\sqrt{2} z_{0} \operatorname{Tr}\left(U S U^{\dagger} \eta^{*}\right)-\operatorname{Tr} S^{2}\right]}{\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{k}}[d S] \int_{\mathrm{U}(k)^{2}} d \mu(U) d \mu(V)\left|\Delta_{k}(S)\right|^{2} \exp \left[-\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \operatorname{Tr}\left(V^{\dagger} S V \chi\right)-\sqrt{2} z_{0} \operatorname{Tr}\left(U S U^{\dagger} \eta^{*}\right)\right]}
\end{aligned}
$$

The group integrals against the normalised Haar measures $d \mu(U) d \mu(V)$ are Harish-Chandra-ItzyksonZuber integrals $[71,59]$ which can be carried out, and after we apply the Andréief integration for-

mula [75] the expression simplifies to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathcal{C}^{k \times k}}[d \tilde{A}] \exp \left[-\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \operatorname{Tr} \tilde{A}^{\dagger} \tilde{A} \chi-\sqrt{2} z_{0} \operatorname{Tr} \tilde{A} \tilde{A}^{\dagger} \eta^{*}-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\tilde{A}^{\dagger} \tilde{A}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =\frac{\pi^{k^{2}}}{\prod_{a, b=1}^{k}\left(\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \chi_{a}+\sqrt{2} z_{0} \eta_{b}^{*}\right)} \frac{\operatorname{det}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} d s \exp \left(-\sqrt{2}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{a}+z_{0} \eta_{b}^{*}\right) s-s^{2}\right)\right]_{a, b=1, \ldots, k}}{\operatorname{det}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} d s \exp \left(-\sqrt{2}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{a}+z_{0} \eta_{b}^{*}\right) s\right)\right]_{a, b=1, \ldots, k}} \\
& =\frac{\pi^{k^{2}}}{\prod_{a, b=1}^{k}\left(\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \chi_{a}+\sqrt{2} z_{0} \eta_{b}^{*}\right)} \frac{\operatorname{det}\left[\frac{\chi_{0}^{*} \chi_{a}+z_{0} \eta_{b}^{*}}{\sqrt{2}}\right] \exp \left(\frac{\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{a}+z_{0} \eta_{b}^{*}\right)^{2}}{2}\right) \int_{a, b=1, \ldots, k} \\
& \operatorname{det}\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{a}+z_{0} \eta_{b}^{*}\right)}\right]_{a, b=1, \ldots, k},
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have used the complementary error function (2.17) once we have completed the squares. The determinant in the denominator is a Cauchy determinant [49] which can be expressed as follows

$$
\operatorname{det}\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{a}+z_{0} \eta_{b}^{*}\right)}\right]_{a, b=1, \ldots, k}=\frac{\Delta_{k}\left(\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \chi\right) \Delta_{k}\left(\sqrt{2} z_{0} \eta^{*}\right)}{\prod_{a, b=1}^{k}\left(\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \chi_{a}+\sqrt{2} z_{0} \eta_{b}^{*}\right)}=2^{k(k-1) / 2} \frac{\Delta_{k}(\chi) \Delta_{k}\left(\eta^{*}\right)}{\prod_{a, b=1}^{k}\left(\sqrt{2} z_{0}^{*} \chi_{a}+\sqrt{2} z_{0} \eta_{b}^{*}\right)}
$$

for which we exploited $\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}=1$ in the second equality. Finally, we put these results together with the normalisation (4.36) and the normalisation from (4.6) given in (3.23), to obtain the simplification (4.41).

Classes $\mathbf{A I}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathbf{A I I}^{\dagger}$ : The very same strategy as for class A to derive (4.35) works out for both, complex symmetric and complex self-dual matrices. The only difference is the rescaling, which is given by $A \rightarrow\left(\frac{2}{d_{N}}\right)^{-1 / 4} A$, and the change of parameters, in particular we need to replace $N \rightarrow d_{N} / 2$, $\chi \rightarrow \operatorname{diag}(\chi / \sqrt{2}, \chi / \sqrt{2})$ and $\eta^{*} \rightarrow \operatorname{diag}\left(\eta^{*} / \sqrt{2}, \eta^{*} / \sqrt{2}\right)$. When expanding along the lines of (4.42), we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{N, k} & \left(z, w^{*}\right)=\exp \left[\sqrt{d_{N}} \operatorname{Tr}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi+z_{0} \eta^{*}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi\right)^{2}+\left(z_{0} \eta^{*}\right)^{2}\right]\right] \\
& \times \frac{\int_{\mathcal{M}}[d A] \exp \left[-\frac{z_{0}^{*}}{\sqrt{2}} \operatorname{Tr} A^{\dagger} A \operatorname{diag}(\chi, \chi)-\frac{z_{0}}{\sqrt{2}} \operatorname{Tr} A A^{\dagger} \operatorname{diag}\left(\eta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2}\right]}{\int_{\mathcal{M}}[d A] \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2}\right]} \quad\left[1+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{M}$ is the set of either the $2 k \times 2 k$ quaternion (for class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ ) or real (for class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ ) matrices. To render this limit mathematically rigorous one needs to cut-off from the original integration the region $\left\|A^{\dagger} A\right\| \geq N^{\varepsilon}$ for some $0<\varepsilon<1 / 6$. Then, the expansion is uniform on the complement while for $\left\|A^{\dagger} A\right\| \geq N^{\varepsilon}$ one can find an exponentially suppressed bound compared to the main contribution about the origin.

Once we normalise along the definitions (4.1) and (4.6), we arrive at (4.35). What is left to do is to compute the normalisation constants (4.37) and (4.38).

Normalisation of Class $\mathbf{A I}^{\dagger}$ : We compute along the same ideas as before to find the normalisation (4.37). We use the result (3.29) and evaluate the integral

$$
\int_{\mathbb{H}^{k \times k}}[d A] \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2}\right]=\int_{\mathbb{H}^{k \times k}}[d A] \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)\right] \frac{\int_{\mathbb{H}^{k \times k}}[d A] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2} / 2\right]}{\int_{\mathbb{H}^{k \times k}}[d A] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right) / 2\right]}
$$

We introduced the factor of $1 / 2$ in the Gaussian due to

$$
\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)=\sum_{l=1}^{4} \sum_{a, b=1}^{k}\left(A_{a b}^{l}\right)^{2}
$$

where $A_{a b}^{l}$ with $l=1,2,3,4$ are the four real components of a quaternion. Like for the complex Ginibre case, we integrate out the Gaussian in the prefactor and go over to a singular value decomposition $A=U \operatorname{diag}(\sqrt{S}, \sqrt{S}) V^{\dagger}$ with $U, V \in \operatorname{USp}(2 k)$ and $S=\operatorname{diag}\left(s_{1}, \ldots, s_{k}\right) \geq 0$ without worrying about the normalisation constants resulting from such a change of variables as those in the numerator and denominator cancel each other,

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{k} \times k}\left[d A \mid \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2}\right]=\pi^{2 k^{2}} \frac{\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{k}}[d S] \mid \Delta_{k}(S)\left.\right|^{4} \operatorname{det} S \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr} S^{2}\right]}{\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{k}}[d S] \mid \Delta_{k}(S)\left.\right|^{4} \operatorname{det} S \exp [-\operatorname{Tr} S]}
$$

Let us recall that the singular values of a quaternion matrix are Kramers degenerate. Anew, we notice that the integral in the denominator is a Selberg integral and employ the result of [74, Eq. (17.6.5)]. For the numerator we use the trick suggested in [51, Sec. 4] and double the number of integration variables by introducing first derivatives of Dirac delta functions,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{k}}[d S]\left|\Delta_{k}(S)\right|^{4} \operatorname{det} S \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr} S^{2}\right] \\
= & \frac{2^{k} k!}{(2 k)!} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2 k}} d s_{1} \cdots d s_{2 k} \Delta_{2 k}\left(s_{1}, \ldots, s_{2 k}\right) \operatorname{Pf}\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(\partial_{a}-\partial_{b}\right) \delta\left(s_{a}-s_{b}\right)\right]_{a, b=1, \ldots, 2 k} \prod_{j=1}^{2 k} \sqrt{s_{j}} e^{-s_{j}^{2} / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The combinatorial prefactor properly normalises the rest which can be checked when expanding the Pfaffian and applying the derivatives. They effectively only act on terms of pairwise differences in the Vandermonde determinant as they would otherwise vanish when evaluating the Dirac delta function, i.e.,

$$
\prod_{j=1}^{k} \frac{1}{2}\left(\partial_{2 j}-\partial_{2 j-1}\right) \Delta_{2 k}\left(s_{1}, \ldots, s_{2 k}\right)\left.\right|_{s_{2 j}=s_{2 j-1}}=\left|\Delta_{k}\left(s_{1}, s_{3}, \ldots, s_{2 k-1}\right)\right|^{4}
$$

The benefit of this way of writing the integral is that we can expand the Vandermonde determinant $\Delta_{2 k}\left(s_{1}, \ldots, s_{2 k}\right)$ and apply de Bruijn's integral identity [76] which yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R}^{k \times k}}[d A] \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2}\right] \\
= & \frac{2^{k} \pi^{2 k^{2}}}{\prod_{j=0}^{k-1}(2 j+2)!(2 j+1)!} \frac{2^{k} k!}{(2 k)!}(2 k)!\operatorname{Pf}\left[\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2}} d s_{1} d s_{2} s_{1}^{a-1 / 2} s_{2}^{b-1 / 2} e^{-\left(s_{1}^{2}+s_{2}^{2}\right) / 2} \frac{1}{2}\left(\partial_{1}-\partial_{2}\right) \delta\left(s_{1}-s_{2}\right)\right]_{a, b=1}^{2 k} \\
= & \frac{\pi^{2 k^{2}}}{\prod_{j=0}^{k-1}[(2 j+1)!]^{2}} \operatorname{Pf}\left[(b-a) \int_{0}^{\infty} d s_{1} s_{1}^{a+b-2} e^{-s_{1}^{2}}\right]_{a, b=1}^{2 k}
\end{aligned}
$$

The remaining integral in the Pfaffian determinant gives $\Gamma[(a+b-1) / 2] / 2$. After multiplying this result with $(2 \pi)^{k / 2}$ originating from (3.29) we arrive at (4.37).

Normalisation of Class AII ${ }^{1}$ : Like before we start from

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mathbb{R}^{2 k \times 2 k}}[d A] \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2}\right] & =\int_{\mathbb{R}^{2 k \times 2 k}}[d A] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)\right] \frac{\int_{\mathbb{R}^{2 k \times 2 k}}[d A] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2} / 2\right]}{\int_{\mathbb{R}^{2 k \times 2 k}}[d A] \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)\right]} \\
& =\pi^{2 k^{2}} \frac{\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2 k}}[d S]\left|\Delta_{2 k}(S)\right| \operatorname{det} S^{-1 / 2} \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr} S^{2} / 2\right]}{\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2 k}}[d S]\left|\Delta_{2 k}(S)\right| \operatorname{det} S^{-1 / 2} \exp [-\operatorname{Tr} S]}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the singular value decomposition is now $A=U \sqrt{S} V^{\dagger}$ with $U, V \in \mathrm{O}(2 k)$ and $S=\operatorname{diag}\left(s_{1}, \ldots, s_{2 k}\right)$. The integral in the denominator is another special case of the Selberg integral in [74, Eq. (17.6.5)] and the numerator can be dealt with the identity [76],

$$
\left|\Delta_{2 k}(S)\right|=\Delta_{2 k}(S) \operatorname{Pf}\left[\operatorname{sign}\left(s_{b}-s_{a}\right)\right]_{a, b=1, \ldots, 2 k}
$$

with $\operatorname{sign}\left(s_{b}-s_{a}\right)=\left(s_{b}-s_{a}\right) /\left|s_{b}-s_{a}\right|$. Applying de Bruijn's integral identity [76] we arrive at

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R}^{2 k \times 2 k}}[d A] \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2}\right] \\
= & \frac{\pi^{2 k^{2}}(2 k)!}{\prod_{j=0}^{2 k-1} 2 \Gamma[(j+3) / 2] \Gamma[(j+1) / 2] / \sqrt{\pi}} \operatorname{Pf}\left[\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2}} d s_{1} d s_{2} \operatorname{sign}\left(s_{2}-s_{1}\right) s_{1}^{a-3 / 2} s_{2}^{b-3 / 2} e^{-\left(s_{1}^{2}+s_{2}^{2}\right) / 2}\right]_{a, b=1}^{2 k}
\end{aligned}
$$

The product of Gamma-functions can be simplified by Legendre's duplication formula by multiplying factors with odd and even $j$ together,

$$
\prod_{j=0}^{2 k-1} 2 \Gamma[(j+3) / 2] \Gamma[(j+1) / 2] / \sqrt{\pi}=\prod_{l=0}^{k-1} 2^{-4 l}(2 l+2)!(2 l)!
$$

The integral in the Pfaffian is feasible when, first, ordering $s_{1} \geq s_{2} \geq 0$ and, then, going over to polar coordinates $s_{1}+i s_{2}=\sqrt{2 r} e^{i \varphi}$ with $\varphi \in[0, \pi / 4]$ to account for $s_{1} \geq s_{2} \geq 0$. This gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2}} d s_{1} d s_{2} \operatorname{sign}\left(s_{2}-s_{1}\right) s_{1}^{a-3 / 2} s_{2}^{b-3 / 2} e^{-\left(s_{1}^{2}+s_{2}^{2}\right) / 2} \\
= & 2^{(a+b-3) / 2} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{d r}{r} r^{(a+b-1) / 2} e^{-r} \int_{0}^{\pi / 4} d \varphi\left[\cos ^{b-3 / 2}(\varphi) \sin ^{a-3 / 2}(\varphi)-\cos ^{a-3 / 2}(\varphi) \sin ^{b-3 / 2}(\varphi)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The integral over $r$ is anew the Gamma-function $\Gamma[(a+b-1) / 2]$ while the integral over $\varphi$ yields essentially a hypergeometric function

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{\pi / 4} d \varphi \cos ^{b-3 / 2}(\varphi) \sin ^{a-3 / 2}(\varphi) & =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{1 / 2} d x(1-x)^{(2 b-5) / 2} x^{(2 a-5) / 4} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \sum_{j=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{j}\binom{(2 b-5) / 4}{j} \frac{2^{-(2 a-1) / 4-j}}{(2 a-1) / 4+j} \\
& =\frac{2^{(5-2 a) / 4}}{2 a-1}{ }_{2} F_{1}\left(\frac{2 a-1}{4}, \frac{5-2 b}{4} ; \frac{2 a+3}{4} ; \frac{1}{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We first substituted $x=\sin ^{2}(\varphi)$ and then expanded $(1-x)^{(2 b-5) / 4}$ in $x$ leading to the binomial series which can be easily integrated. The difference of this expression with $a$ and $b$ yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R}^{2 k \times 2 k}}[d A] \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{\dagger} A\right)^{2}\right]=\frac{\pi^{2 k^{2}}}{\prod_{l=0}^{k-1} 2^{-4 l}[(2 l)!]^{2}} \\
& \quad \times \operatorname{Pf}\left[2^{-1 / 4} \Gamma\left[\frac{a+b-1}{2}\right]\left(\frac{2^{b / 2}}{2 a-1}{ }_{2} F_{1}\left(\frac{2 a-1}{4}, \frac{5-2 b}{4} ; \frac{2 a+3}{4} ; \frac{1}{2}\right)-\{a \leftrightarrow b\}\right)\right]_{a, b=1}^{2 k}
\end{aligned}
$$

When pulling the factor $2^{-1 / 4}$ out of the Pfaffian and multiplying it with $[\sqrt{4 \pi} / \operatorname{arctanh}(1 / \sqrt{2})]^{k}$ coming from (3.29) we arrive at (4.38).

# 5 Conclusions and open problems 

We provided analytical results for three ensembles of non-Hermitian random matrices, the complex Ginibre ensemble (Cartan class A), complex symmetric matrices (Cartan class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ ) and complex self-dual random matrices (Cartan class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ ). Choosing expectation values of $k$ pairs of conjugate characteristic polynomials as correlations functions, we proved that indeed all three ensembles lead to different local bulk and edge statistics for the complex eigenvalues. The explicit expressions for $k=1$ pair in class $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$, see Proposition 2.1, show a remarkably similar structure to the well known respective answer for the complex Ginibre ensemble for finite- $N$, being given in terms of sums of truncated exponentials. This allowed us to derive asymptotic results in the local bulk and edge scaling limit, as well as for the global large- $N$ limit, with different results in all three limits for each ensemble, cf., Propositions 3.1 and 3.3 and Theorem 3.2. In particular, the resulting properties at the edge are compatible with the expected behaviour of the spectral density based on an approximate Coulomb gas description with three different values of inverse temperature $\beta$.

For general $k$ we have identified the effective Lagrangians in the local bulk (Theorem 4.1) and in the edge scaling limit (Theorem 4.2). In both limits the respective Lagrangians agree for all three classes. However, the integration domain differs for each ensemble. In the bulk it is given by the compact unitary, unitary symplectic and orthogonal group for class $\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$, respectively. At the edge, integrals over complex, quaternion and real valued matrices result. Only in class A these group integrals can be performed for $k>1$ and mapped to known results. Also here, from the known properties of these integrals it is clear that all three ensembles differ. We expect that these effective Lagrangians as well as Goldstone manifolds will be universal and should be shared with physical systems with the corresponding symmetries. The effective Lagrangians (4.4) and (4.5) would then appear as the potential part of the corresponding non-linear $\sigma$-models.

Several open questions prevail for these three representatives of local bulk and edge statistics. Is it possible to access more detailed spectral information in the two classes $\mathrm{AI}^{\dagger}$ and $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$, despite the lack of a joint eigenvalue density? Can we analytically prove universality in these two cases by deforming the Gaussian ensembles considered so far? More generally, is it possible to prove that all other known non-Hermitian symmetry classes fall into these three classes, away form their symmetry axes and symmetry points? We plan to come back to some of these questions in future work.

# A Differential equation for class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ and the edge scaling limit 

In this appendix, we derive a differential equation for the integral representation for the expected characteristic polynomials in class $\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}$ at finite $N$, see Subsection 2.3,

$$
D_{N}^{\mathrm{AII}^{\dagger}}\left(\left.z, w^{*}\right)\right|_{x=z w^{*}}=\frac{1}{4^{N}} f_{N}(x), \quad f_{N}(x)=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v e^{-v} \int_{-v}^{v} d u\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N}
$$

in the form (2.62) which we need here. We will also show how this could be employed to derive the edge scaling limit in this class.

From the above integral we obtain for $x \neq 0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial}{\partial x} f_{N}(x) & =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v e^{-v} \int_{-v}^{v} d u N(8 x+4 v)\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N-1} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v e^{-v} \int_{-v}^{v} d u N\left(4 x+\frac{4 x^{2}+4 v x+u^{2}}{x}-\frac{u^{2}}{x}\right)\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N-1} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v e^{-v} \int_{-v}^{v} d u\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial v}+\frac{N}{x}-\frac{u}{2 x} \frac{\partial}{\partial u}\right)\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N}
\end{aligned}
$$

While the middle term immediately gives back $\frac{N}{x} f_{N}(x)$, the two terms with derivatives with respect to $v$ and $u$ can be simplified using integration by parts.

For the third term differentiated with respect to $u$ we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v e^{-v}\left\{\left[-\frac{u}{2 x}\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N}\right]_{-v}^{v}+\int_{-v}^{v} d u \frac{1}{2 x}\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N}\right\} \\
& =-\frac{1}{2 x} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v e^{-v} v(2 x+v)^{2 N}+\frac{1}{2 x} f_{N}(x) \\
& =-\frac{1}{2 x} e^{2 x} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v e^{-v-2 x}\left((2 x+v)^{2 N+1}-2 x(2 x+v)^{N}\right)+\frac{1}{2 x} f_{N}(x) \\
& =-\frac{1}{2 x} e^{2 x}(\Gamma(2 N+2,2 x)-2 x \Gamma(2 N+1,2 x))+\frac{1}{2 x} f_{N}(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

For the first term in (A.2) we consider the following total derivative:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{d}{d v} \int_{-v}^{v} d u e^{-v}\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N} \\
& =2 e^{-v}\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+v^{2}\right)^{N}-\int_{-v}^{v} d u e^{-v}\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N}+\int_{-v}^{v} d u e^{-v} \frac{\partial}{\partial v}\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N}
\end{aligned}
$$

Integrating this expression over $v$ from zero to infinity, the boundary terms on the left hand side obviously vanish, and we arrive at

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & =\int_{0}^{\infty} d v e^{-v}(2 x+v)^{2 N}-f_{N}(x)+\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v \int_{-v}^{v} d u e^{-v} \frac{\partial}{\partial v}\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N} \\
& =e^{2 x} \Gamma(2 N+1,2 x)-f_{N}(x)+\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} d v \int_{-v}^{v} d u e^{-v} \frac{\partial}{\partial v}\left(4 x^{2}+4 x v+u^{2}\right)^{N}
\end{aligned}
$$

Inserting this expression together with (A.3) into (A.2) we obtain as a final result

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial x} f_{N}(x)=\left(1+\frac{N}{x}+\frac{1}{2 x}\right) f_{N}(x)-\frac{1}{2 x} e^{2 x} \Gamma(2 N+2,2 x)
$$

We note that two terms with the incomplete Gamma-function $\Gamma(2 N+1,2 x)$ cancel.
This can be translated into an equation for the rescaled quantity

$$
F_{N}(x)=\frac{1}{(2 N)!} e^{-2 x} f_{N}(x)=e^{-2 z w^{*}} \frac{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AH}^{\dagger}}\left(z, w^{*}\right)}{D_{N}^{\mathrm{AH}^{\dagger}}(0,0)}\left.\right|_{x=z w^{*}}
$$

see (3.3), in order to take the edge (and bulk) large- $N$ limit. It gives the following differential equation

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial x} F_{N}(x)=\left(\frac{2 N+1}{2 x}-1\right) F_{N}(x)-\frac{1}{2 x} \frac{\Gamma(2 N+2,2 x)}{\Gamma(2 N+1)}
$$

Let us briefly indicate how (A.8) can be used to alternatively derive the edge scaling limit (3.22). Employing the scaling

$$
x=N+\sqrt{N} y+\chi \eta^{*} / 2
$$

while keeping $y=\left(z_{0}^{*} \xi+z_{0} \eta^{*}\right) / \sqrt{2}$ fixed, the partial derivatives are related like

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial x}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \frac{\partial}{\partial y}
$$

This implies for (A.8) that

$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \frac{\partial}{\partial y} F_{N}(x)=\left[-\frac{y}{\sqrt{N}}+O\left(N^{-1}\right)\right] F_{N}(x)-\left[1+O\left(N^{-1 / 2}\right)\right] \frac{\Gamma(2 N+2,2 x)}{\Gamma(2 N+2)}
$$

Due to (2.16) and its asymptotic (3.20) we have

$$
\frac{\Gamma(2 N+2,2 x)}{\Gamma(2 N+2)}=Q(2 N+2,2 x)=\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{erfc}(y)+O\left(N^{-1 / 2}\right)
$$

From this we deduce that the limit $F(y)=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} F_{N}(x) / \sqrt{2 N}$ satisfies the differential equation

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial y} F(y)=-y F(y)-\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}} \operatorname{erfc}(y)
$$

The solution of the homogeneous solution $F_{h}(y)$ is given by

$$
F_{h}(y)=C e^{-y^{2} / 2}
$$

In order to find a special solution $F_{s}(y)$ to the inhomogeneous equation (A.13), we vary the integration constant, setting $F_{s}(y)=g(y / \sqrt{2}) e^{-y^{2} / 2}$ which reduces (A.13) to

$$
g^{\prime}(v)=-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{erfc}(\sqrt{2} v) e^{+v^{2}} \quad \text { with } \quad v=y / \sqrt{2}
$$

It is identical to (3.45) and further motivates why we have introduced this function. From here onwards we can proceed as in Subsection 3.3 to arrive at (3.25). The bulk scaling limit can be derived from (A.11) in a similar fashion.

# B Relation to the orthogonal polynomial approach in class A 

In this appendix, we make contact with an earlier result for the expectation value of products of characteristic polynomials and their complex conjugates derived in [46, 49]. It is valid for any determinantal point process of orthogonal polynomial type, having a joint density of complex (or real) eigenvalues that includes the modulus square of the Vandermonde determinant, see (4.10). A special case of the theorem proven in [46], when the number $k$ of factors and conjugate factors agrees, is given by

$$
\widetilde{D}_{N, k}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right):=\left\langle\prod_{j=1}^{k} \operatorname{det}\left[z_{j} \mathbf{1}_{N}-J\right] \operatorname{det}\left[w_{j}^{*} \mathbf{1}_{N}-J^{*}\right]\right\rangle=\prod_{i=N}^{N+k-1} h_{i} \frac{\operatorname{det}_{j, l=1}^{k}\left[K_{N+k}\left(z_{j}, w_{l}^{*}\right)\right]}{\Delta_{k}(Z) \Delta_{k}\left(W^{*}\right)}
$$

with $W=\operatorname{diag}\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{k}\right)$. Here, the expectation value defined in (2.3) is taken with respect to class A, cf. eq. (2.4). The $h_{j}$ are the squared norms of the orthogonal polynomials $P_{j}(z)=z^{j}+\mathcal{O}\left(z^{j-1}\right)$ in monic normalisation, and

$$
K_{N}\left(z, w^{*}\right)=\sum_{j=0}^{N-1} \frac{1}{h_{j}} P_{j}(z) P_{j}\left(w^{*}\right)
$$

is the polynomial part of the kernel (also known as pre-kernel). In the particular case of the complex Ginibre ensemble we have

$$
K_{N}\left(z, w^{*}\right)=E_{N-1}\left(z w^{*}\right), \quad P_{j}(z)=z^{j}, \quad h_{j}=j!
$$

In particular, setting $k=1$ in (B.1) for this case we obtain (3.12).
In Section 4, explicit expressions in terms of $k$-dimensional group integrals were given for such expectation values for $k>1$ for all three ensembles, in the bulk and at the edge. For class A these group integrals can be solved, with the resulting expressions (4.9) and (4.36) to be rederived here.

The asymptotic of the kernel in (B.1) in the bulk and at the edge were already discussed in Subsection 3.2 so that we can be very brief. In line with Section 4, we recall the scaling of the $k$ arguments,

$$
\begin{aligned}
Z & =\sqrt{N} z_{0} \mathbf{1}_{k}+\chi, \quad \chi=\operatorname{diag}\left(\chi_{1}, \ldots, \chi_{k}\right) \\
W & =\sqrt{N} z_{0} \mathbf{1}_{k}+\eta, \quad \eta=\operatorname{diag}\left(\eta_{1}, \ldots, \eta_{k}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Due to the translational invariance of the Vandermonde determinant (4.10), it immediately follows that $\Delta_{k}(Z)=\Delta_{k}(\chi)$, and likewise for $\Delta_{k}\left(W^{*}\right)=\Delta_{k}\left(\eta^{*}\right)$.

In bulk scaling for $\left|z_{0}\right|<1$, we insert (3.16) into (B.1) to arrive at

$$
\left.\widetilde{D}_{N, k}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right)\right|_{\left|z_{0}\right|<1} \sim\left(\prod_{j=N}^{N+k-1} j!\right) \exp \left[k N\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}+\sqrt{N} \sum_{j=1}^{k}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{j}+z_{0} \eta_{j}^{*}\right)\right] \frac{\operatorname{det}_{i, j=1}^{k}\left[\exp \left[\chi_{i} \eta_{j}^{*}\right]\right]}{\Delta_{k}(\chi) \Delta_{k}\left(\eta^{*}\right)}
$$

This has to be normalised by the product of the individual expectation values, for which it immediately follows

$$
\prod_{j=1}^{k} \widetilde{D}_{N, 1}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(\sqrt{N} z_{0}+\chi_{j}, \sqrt{N} z_{0}^{*}+\eta_{j}^{*}\right) \mid_{\left|z_{0}\right|<1} \sim(N!)^{k} \exp \left[\sum_{j=1}^{k}\left(N\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}+\sqrt{N}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{j}+z_{0} \eta_{j}^{*}\right)+\chi_{j} \eta_{j}^{*}\right)\right]
$$

After taking the ratio (4.6) with $D_{N, k}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right)=\widetilde{D}_{N, k}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right) / \widetilde{D}_{N, k}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(z_{0} \mathbf{1}_{k}, z_{0}^{*} \mathbf{1}_{k}\right)$ all factorials and most of the exponential pre-factors cancel, leading to the result (4.9) in Section 4.

When turning to the edge scaling limit, with $\left|z_{0}\right|=1$, the only difference resulting from the limiting kernel (3.21) is the extra factor of the complementary error function,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left.\tilde{D}_{N, k}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(Z, W^{*}\right)\right|_{\left|z_{0}\right|=1} \sim & \left(\prod_{j=N}^{N+k-1} j!\right) \exp \left[k N\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}+\sqrt{N} \sum_{j=1}^{k}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{j}+z_{0} \eta_{j}^{*}\right)\right] \\
& \times \frac{\operatorname{det}_{i, j=1}^{k}\left[\exp \left[\chi_{i} \eta_{j}^{*}\right] \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{i}+z_{0} \eta_{j}^{*}\right)\right)\right]}{\Delta_{k}(\chi) \Delta_{k}\left(\eta^{*}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

In comparison, the normalising product of the expectation values for $k=1$ are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\prod_{j=1}^{k} \tilde{D}_{N, 1}^{\mathrm{A}}\left(\sqrt{N} z_{0}+\chi_{j}, \sqrt{N} z_{0}^{*}+\eta_{j}^{*}\right) \mid_{\left|z_{0}\right|=1} \sim & (N!)^{k} \exp \left[k N\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}+\sqrt{N} \sum_{j=1}^{k}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{j}+z_{0} \eta_{j}^{*}\right)\right] \\
& \times e^{\sum_{j=1}^{k} \chi_{j} \eta_{j}^{*}} \prod_{l=1}^{k} \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(z_{0}^{*} \chi_{l}+z_{0} \eta_{l}^{*}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Once again the factors in the first line cancel those in (B.7) when taking the ratio. This agrees with (4.41) in Section 4.

abstract:
Recently, a conjecture about the local bulk statistics of complex eigenvalues
has been made based on numerics. It claims that there are only three
universality classes, which have all been observed in open chaotic quantum
systems. Motivated by these new insights, we compute and compare the
expectation values of $k$ pairs of complex conjugate characteristic polynomials
in three ensembles of Gaussian non-Hermitian random matrices representative for
the three classes: the well-known complex Ginibre ensemble, complex symmetric
and complex self-dual matrices. In the Cartan classification scheme of
non-Hermitian random matrices they are labelled as class A, AI$^\dag$ and
AII$^\dag$, respectively. Using the technique of Grassmann variables, we derive
explicit expressions for a single pair of expected characteristic polynomials
for finite as well as infinite matrix dimension. For the latter we consider the
global limit as well as zoom into the edge and the bulk of the spectrum,
providing new analytical results for classes AI$^\dag$ and AII$^\dag$. For
general $k$, we derive the effective Lagrangians corresponding to the
non-linear $\sigma$-models in the respective physical systems. Interestingly,
they agree for all three ensembles, while the corresponding Goldstone
manifolds, over which one has to perform the remaining integrations, are
different and equal the three classical compact groups in the bulk. In
particular, our analytical results show that these three ensembles have indeed
different local bulk and edge spectral statistics, corroborating the conjecture
further.
